title: Sonnet I
couplet: FROM fairest creatures we desire increase,/That thereby beauty's rose might never die,

title: Sonnet I
couplet: But as the riper should by time decease,/His tender heir might bear his memory:

title: Sonnet I
couplet: But thou, contracted to thine own bright eyes,/Feed'st thy light'st flame with self-substantial fuel,

title: Sonnet I
couplet: Making a famine where abundance lies,/Thyself thy foe, to thy sweet self too cruel.

title: Sonnet I
couplet: Thou that art now the world's fresh ornament/And only herald to the gaudy spring,

title: Sonnet I
couplet: Within thine own bud buriest thy content/And, tender churl, makest waste in niggarding.

title: Sonnet I
couplet: Pity the world, or else this glutton be,/  To eat the world's due, by the grave and thee.

title: Sonnet II
couplet: When forty winters shall beseige thy brow,/And dig deep trenches in thy beauty's field,

title: Sonnet II
couplet: Thy youth's proud livery, so gazed on now,/Will be a tatter'd weed, of small worth held:

title: Sonnet II
couplet: Then being ask'd where all thy beauty lies,/Where all the treasure of thy lusty days,

title: Sonnet II
couplet: To say, within thine own deep-sunken eyes,/Were an all-eating shame and thriftless praise.

title: Sonnet II
couplet: How much more praise deserved thy beauty's use,/If thou couldst answer 'This fair child of mine

title: Sonnet II
couplet: Shall sum my count and make my old excuse,'/Proving his beauty by succession thine!

title: Sonnet II
couplet: This were to be new made when thou art old,/  And see thy blood warm when thou feel'st it cold.

title: Sonnet III
couplet: Look in thy glass, and tell the face thou viewest/Now is the time that face should form another;

title: Sonnet III
couplet: Whose fresh repair if now thou not renewest,/Thou dost beguile the world, unbless some mother.

title: Sonnet III
couplet: For where is she so fair whose unear'd womb/Disdains the tillage of thy husbandry?

title: Sonnet III
couplet: Or who is he so fond will be the tomb/Of his self-love, to stop posterity?

title: Sonnet III
couplet: Thou art thy mother's glass, and she in thee/Calls back the lovely April of her prime:

title: Sonnet III
couplet: So thou through windows of thine age shall see/Despite of wrinkles this thy golden time.

title: Sonnet III
couplet: But if thou live, remember'd not to be,/  Die single, and thine image dies with thee.

title: Sonnet IV
couplet: Unthrifty loveliness, why dost thou spend/Upon thyself thy beauty's legacy?

title: Sonnet IV
couplet: Nature's bequest gives nothing but doth lend,/And being frank she lends to those are free.

title: Sonnet IV
couplet: Then, beauteous niggard, why dost thou abuse/The bounteous largess given thee to give?

title: Sonnet IV
couplet: Profitless usurer, why dost thou use/So great a sum of sums, yet canst not live?

title: Sonnet IV
couplet: For having traffic with thyself alone,/Thou of thyself thy sweet self dost deceive.

title: Sonnet IV
couplet: Then how, when nature calls thee to be gone,/What acceptable audit canst thou leave?

title: Sonnet IV
couplet: Thy unused beauty must be tomb'd with thee,/  Which, used, lives th' executor to be.

title: Sonnet V
couplet: Those hours, that with gentle work did frame/The lovely gaze where every eye doth dwell,

title: Sonnet V
couplet: Will play the tyrants to the very same/And that unfair which fairly doth excel:

title: Sonnet V
couplet: For never-resting time leads summer on/To hideous winter and confounds him there;

title: Sonnet V
couplet: Sap cheque'd with frost and lusty leaves quite gone,/Beauty o'ersnow'd and bareness every where:

title: Sonnet V
couplet: Then, were not summer's distillation left,/A liquid prisoner pent in walls of glass,

title: Sonnet V
couplet: Beauty's effect with beauty were bereft,/Nor it nor no remembrance what it was:

title: Sonnet V
couplet: But flowers distill'd though they with winter meet,/  Leese but their show; their substance still lives sweet.

title: Sonnet VI
couplet: Then let not winter's ragged hand deface/In thee thy summer, ere thou be distill'd:

title: Sonnet VI
couplet: Make sweet some vial; treasure thou some place/With beauty's treasure, ere it be self-kill'd.

title: Sonnet VI
couplet: That use is not forbidden usury,/Which happies those that pay the willing loan;

title: Sonnet VI
couplet: That's for thyself to breed another thee,/Or ten times happier, be it ten for one;

title: Sonnet VI
couplet: Ten times thyself were happier than thou art,/If ten of thine ten times refigured thee:

title: Sonnet VI
couplet: Then what could death do, if thou shouldst depart,/Leaving thee living in posterity?

title: Sonnet VI
couplet: Be not self-will'd, for thou art much too fair/  To be death's conquest and make worms thine heir.

title: Sonnet VII
couplet: Lo! in the orient when the gracious light/Lifts up his burning head, each under eye

title: Sonnet VII
couplet: Doth homage to his new-appearing sight,/Serving with looks his sacred majesty;

title: Sonnet VII
couplet: And having climb'd the steep-up heavenly hill,/Resembling strong youth in his middle age,

title: Sonnet VII
couplet: yet mortal looks adore his beauty still,/Attending on his golden pilgrimage;

title: Sonnet VII
couplet: But when from highmost pitch, with weary car,/Like feeble age, he reeleth from the day,

title: Sonnet VII
couplet: The eyes, 'fore duteous, now converted are/From his low tract and look another way:

title: Sonnet VII
couplet: So thou, thyself out-going in thy noon,/  Unlook'd on diest, unless thou get a son.

title: Sonnet VIII
couplet: Music to hear, why hear'st thou music sadly?/Sweets with sweets war not, joy delights in joy.

title: Sonnet VIII
couplet: Why lovest thou that which thou receivest not gladly,/Or else receivest with pleasure thine annoy?

title: Sonnet VIII
couplet: If the true concord of well-tuned sounds,/By unions married, do offend thine ear,

title: Sonnet VIII
couplet: They do but sweetly chide thee, who confounds/In singleness the parts that thou shouldst bear.

title: Sonnet VIII
couplet: Mark how one string, sweet husband to another,/Strikes each in each by mutual ordering,

title: Sonnet VIII
couplet: Resembling sire and child and happy mother/Who all in one, one pleasing note do sing:

title: Sonnet VIII
couplet: Whose speechless song, being many, seeming one,/  Sings this to thee: 'thou single wilt prove none.'

title: Sonnet IX
couplet: Is it for fear to wet a widow's eye/That thou consumest thyself in single life?

title: Sonnet IX
couplet: Ah! if thou issueless shalt hap to die./The world will wail thee, like a makeless wife;

title: Sonnet IX
couplet: The world will be thy widow and still weep/That thou no form of thee hast left behind,

title: Sonnet IX
couplet: When every private widow well may keep/By children's eyes her husband's shape in mind.

title: Sonnet IX
couplet: Look, what an unthrift in the world doth spend/Shifts but his place, for still the world enjoys it;

title: Sonnet IX
couplet: But beauty's waste hath in the world an end,/And kept unused, the user so destroys it.

title: Sonnet IX
couplet: No love toward others in that bosom sits/  That on himself such murderous shame commits.

title: Sonnet X
couplet: For shame! deny that thou bear'st love to any,/Who for thyself art so unprovident.

title: Sonnet X
couplet: Grant, if thou wilt, thou art beloved of many,/But that thou none lovest is most evident;

title: Sonnet X
couplet: For thou art so possess'd with murderous hate/That 'gainst thyself thou stick'st not to conspire.

title: Sonnet X
couplet: Seeking that beauteous roof to ruinate/Which to repair should be thy chief desire.

title: Sonnet X
couplet: O, change thy thought, that I may change my mind!/Shall hate be fairer lodged than gentle love?

title: Sonnet X
couplet: Be, as thy presence is, gracious and kind,/Or to thyself at least kind-hearted prove:

title: Sonnet X
couplet: Make thee another self, for love of me,/  That beauty still may live in thine or thee.

title: Sonnet XI
couplet: As fast as thou shalt wane, so fast thou growest/In one of thine, from that which thou departest;

title: Sonnet XI
couplet: And that fresh blood which youngly thou bestowest/Thou mayst call thine when thou from youth convertest.

title: Sonnet XI
couplet: Herein lives wisdom, beauty and increase:/Without this, folly, age and cold decay:

title: Sonnet XI
couplet: If all were minded so, the times should cease/And threescore year would make the world away.

title: Sonnet XI
couplet: Let those whom Nature hath not made for store,/Harsh featureless and rude, barrenly perish:

title: Sonnet XI
couplet: Look, whom she best endow'd she gave the more;/Which bounteous gift thou shouldst in bounty cherish:

title: Sonnet XI
couplet: She carved thee for her seal, and meant thereby/  Thou shouldst print more, not let that copy die.

title: Sonnet XII
couplet: When I do count the clock that tells the time,/And see the brave day sunk in hideous night;

title: Sonnet XII
couplet: When I behold the violet past prime,/And sable curls all silver'd o'er with white;

title: Sonnet XII
couplet: When lofty trees I see barren of leaves/Which erst from heat did canopy the herd,

title: Sonnet XII
couplet: And summer's green all girded up in sheaves/Borne on the bier with white and bristly beard,

title: Sonnet XII
couplet: Then of thy beauty do I question make,/That thou among the wastes of time must go,

title: Sonnet XII
couplet: Since sweets and beauties do themselves forsake/And die as fast as they see others grow;

title: Sonnet XII
couplet: And nothing 'gainst Time's scythe can make defence/  Save breed, to brave him when he takes thee hence.

title: Sonnet XIII
couplet: O, that you were yourself! but, love, you are/No longer yours than you yourself here live:

title: Sonnet XIII
couplet: Against this coming end you should prepare,/And your sweet semblance to some other give.

title: Sonnet XIII
couplet: So should that beauty which you hold in lease/Find no determination: then you were

title: Sonnet XIII
couplet: Yourself again after yourself's decease,/When your sweet issue your sweet form should bear.

title: Sonnet XIII
couplet: Who lets so fair a house fall to decay,/Which husbandry in honour might uphold

title: Sonnet XIII
couplet: Against the stormy gusts of winter's day/And barren rage of death's eternal cold?

title: Sonnet XIII
couplet: O, none but unthrifts! Dear my love, you know/  You had a father: let your son say so.

title: Sonnet XIV
couplet: Not from the stars do I my judgment pluck;/And yet methinks I have astronomy,

title: Sonnet XIV
couplet: But not to tell of good or evil luck,/Of plagues, of dearths, or seasons' quality;

title: Sonnet XIV
couplet: Nor can I fortune to brief minutes tell,/Pointing to each his thunder, rain and wind,

title: Sonnet XIV
couplet: Or say with princes if it shall go well,/By oft predict that I in heaven find:

title: Sonnet XIV
couplet: But from thine eyes my knowledge I derive,/And, constant stars, in them I read such art

title: Sonnet XIV
couplet: As truth and beauty shall together thrive,/If from thyself to store thou wouldst convert;

title: Sonnet XIV
couplet: Or else of thee this I prognosticate:/  Thy end is truth's and beauty's doom and date.

title: Sonnet XV
couplet: When I consider every thing that grows/Holds in perfection but a little moment,

title: Sonnet XV
couplet: That this huge stage presenteth nought but shows/Whereon the stars in secret influence comment;

title: Sonnet XV
couplet: When I perceive that men as plants increase,/Cheered and cheque'd even by the self-same sky,

title: Sonnet XV
couplet: Vaunt in their youthful sap, at height decrease,/And wear their brave state out of memory;

title: Sonnet XV
couplet: Then the conceit of this inconstant stay/Sets you most rich in youth before my sight,

title: Sonnet XV
couplet: Where wasteful Time debateth with Decay,/To change your day of youth to sullied night;

title: Sonnet XV
couplet: And all in war with Time for love of you,/  As he takes from you, I engraft you new.

title: Sonnet XVI
couplet: But wherefore do not you a mightier way/Make war upon this bloody tyrant, Time?

title: Sonnet XVI
couplet: And fortify yourself in your decay/With means more blessed than my barren rhyme?

title: Sonnet XVI
couplet: Now stand you on the top of happy hours,/And many maiden gardens yet unset

title: Sonnet XVI
couplet: With virtuous wish would bear your living flowers,/Much liker than your painted counterfeit:

title: Sonnet XVI
couplet: So should the lines of life that life repair,/Which this, Time's pencil, or my pupil pen,

title: Sonnet XVI
couplet: Neither in inward worth nor outward fair,/Can make you live yourself in eyes of men.

title: Sonnet XVI
couplet: To give away yourself keeps yourself still,/  And you must live, drawn by your own sweet skill.

title: Sonnet XVII
couplet: Who will believe my verse in time to come,/If it were fill'd with your most high deserts?

title: Sonnet XVII
couplet: Though yet, heaven knows, it is but as a tomb/Which hides your life and shows not half your parts.

title: Sonnet XVII
couplet: If I could write the beauty of your eyes/And in fresh numbers number all your graces,

title: Sonnet XVII
couplet: The age to come would say 'This poet lies:/Such heavenly touches ne'er touch'd earthly faces.'

title: Sonnet XVII
couplet: So should my papers yellow'd with their age/Be scorn'd like old men of less truth than tongue,

title: Sonnet XVII
couplet: And your true rights be term'd a poet's rage/And stretched metre of an antique song:

title: Sonnet XVII
couplet: But were some child of yours alive that time,/  You should live twice; in it and in my rhyme.

title: Sonnet XVIII
couplet: Shall I compare thee to a summer's day?/Thou art more lovely and more temperate:

title: Sonnet XVIII
couplet: Rough winds do shake the darling buds of May,/And summer's lease hath all too short a date:

title: Sonnet XVIII
couplet: Sometime too hot the eye of heaven shines,/And often is his gold complexion dimm'd;

title: Sonnet XVIII
couplet: And every fair from fair sometime declines,/By chance or nature's changing course untrimm'd;

title: Sonnet XVIII
couplet: But thy eternal summer shall not fade/Nor lose possession of that fair thou owest;

title: Sonnet XVIII
couplet: Nor shall Death brag thou wander'st in his shade,/When in eternal lines to time thou growest:

title: Sonnet XVIII
couplet: So long as men can breathe or eyes can see,/  So long lives this and this gives life to thee.

title: Sonnet XIX
couplet: Devouring Time, blunt thou the lion's paws,/And make the earth devour her own sweet brood;

title: Sonnet XIX
couplet: Pluck the keen teeth from the fierce tiger's jaws,/And burn the long-lived phoenix in her blood;

title: Sonnet XIX
couplet: Make glad and sorry seasons as thou fleets,/And do whate'er thou wilt, swift-footed Time,

title: Sonnet XIX
couplet: To the wide world and all her fading sweets;/But I forbid thee one most heinous crime:

title: Sonnet XIX
couplet: O, carve not with thy hours my love's fair brow,/Nor draw no lines there with thine antique pen;

title: Sonnet XIX
couplet: Him in thy course untainted do allow/For beauty's pattern to succeeding men.

title: Sonnet XIX
couplet: Yet, do thy worst, old Time: despite thy wrong,/  My love shall in my verse ever live young.

title: Sonnet XX
couplet: A woman's face with Nature's own hand painted/Hast thou, the master-mistress of my passion;

title: Sonnet XX
couplet: A woman's gentle heart, but not acquainted/With shifting change, as is false women's fashion;

title: Sonnet XX
couplet: An eye more bright than theirs, less false in rolling,/Gilding the object whereupon it gazeth;

title: Sonnet XX
couplet: A man in hue, all 'hues' in his controlling,/Much steals men's eyes and women's souls amazeth.

title: Sonnet XX
couplet: And for a woman wert thou first created;/Till Nature, as she wrought thee, fell a-doting,

title: Sonnet XX
couplet: And by addition me of thee defeated,/By adding one thing to my purpose nothing.

title: Sonnet XX
couplet: But since she prick'd thee out for women's pleasure,/  Mine be thy love and thy love's use their treasure.

title: Sonnet XXI
couplet: So is it not with me as with that Muse/Stirr'd by a painted beauty to his verse,

title: Sonnet XXI
couplet: Who heaven itself for ornament doth use/And every fair with his fair doth rehearse

title: Sonnet XXI
couplet: Making a couplement of proud compare,/With sun and moon, with earth and sea's rich gems,

title: Sonnet XXI
couplet: With April's first-born flowers, and all things rare/That heaven's air in this huge rondure hems.

title: Sonnet XXI
couplet: O' let me, true in love, but truly write,/And then believe me, my love is as fair

title: Sonnet XXI
couplet: As any mother's child, though not so bright/As those gold candles fix'd in heaven's air:

title: Sonnet XXI
couplet: Let them say more than like of hearsay well;/  I will not praise that purpose not to sell.

title: Sonnet XXII
couplet: My glass shall not persuade me I am old,/So long as youth and thou are of one date;

title: Sonnet XXII
couplet: But when in thee time's furrows I behold,/Then look I death my days should expiate.

title: Sonnet XXII
couplet: For all that beauty that doth cover thee/Is but the seemly raiment of my heart,

title: Sonnet XXII
couplet: Which in thy breast doth live, as thine in me:/How can I then be elder than thou art?

title: Sonnet XXII
couplet: O, therefore, love, be of thyself so wary/As I, not for myself, but for thee will;

title: Sonnet XXII
couplet: Bearing thy heart, which I will keep so chary/As tender nurse her babe from faring ill.

title: Sonnet XXII
couplet: Presume not on thy heart when mine is slain;/  Thou gavest me thine, not to give back again.

title: Sonnet XXIII
couplet: As an unperfect actor on the stage/Who with his fear is put besides his part,

title: Sonnet XXIII
couplet: Or some fierce thing replete with too much rage,/Whose strength's abundance weakens his own heart.

title: Sonnet XXIII
couplet: So I, for fear of trust, forget to say/The perfect ceremony of love's rite,

title: Sonnet XXIII
couplet: And in mine own love's strength seem to decay,/O'ercharged with burden of mine own love's might.

title: Sonnet XXIII
couplet: O, let my books be then the eloquence/And dumb presagers of my speaking breast,

title: Sonnet XXIII
couplet: Who plead for love and look for recompense/More than that tongue that more hath more express'd.

title: Sonnet XXIII
couplet: O, learn to read what silent love hath writ:/  To hear with eyes belongs to love's fine wit.

title: Sonnet XXIV
couplet: Mine eye hath play'd the painter and hath stell'd/Thy beauty's form in table of my heart;

title: Sonnet XXIV
couplet: My body is the frame wherein 'tis held,/And perspective it is the painter's art.

title: Sonnet XXIV
couplet: For through the painter must you see his skill,/To find where your true image pictured lies;

title: Sonnet XXIV
couplet: Which in my bosom's shop is hanging still,/That hath his windows glazed with thine eyes.

title: Sonnet XXIV
couplet: Now see what good turns eyes for eyes have done:/Mine eyes have drawn thy shape, and thine for me

title: Sonnet XXIV
couplet: Are windows to my breast, where-through the sun/Delights to peep, to gaze therein on thee;

title: Sonnet XXIV
couplet: Yet eyes this cunning want to grace their art;/  They draw but what they see, know not the heart.

title: Sonnet XXV
couplet: Let those who are in favour with their stars/Of public honour and proud titles boast,

title: Sonnet XXV
couplet: Whilst I, whom fortune of such triumph bars,/Unlook'd for joy in that I honour most.

title: Sonnet XXV
couplet: Great princes' favourites their fair leaves spread/But as the marigold at the sun's eye,

title: Sonnet XXV
couplet: And in themselves their pride lies buried,/For at a frown they in their glory die.

title: Sonnet XXV
couplet: The painful warrior famoused for fight,/After a thousand victories once foil'd,

title: Sonnet XXV
couplet: Is from the book of honour razed quite,/And all the rest forgot for which he toil'd:

title: Sonnet XXV
couplet: Then happy I, that love and am beloved/  Where I may not remove nor be removed.

title: Sonnet XXVI
couplet: Lord of my love, to whom in vassalage/Thy merit hath my duty strongly knit,

title: Sonnet XXVI
couplet: To thee I send this written embassage,/To witness duty, not to show my wit:

title: Sonnet XXVI
couplet: Duty so great, which wit so poor as mine/May make seem bare, in wanting words to show it,

title: Sonnet XXVI
couplet: But that I hope some good conceit of thine/In thy soul's thought, all naked, will bestow it;

title: Sonnet XXVI
couplet: Till whatsoever star that guides my moving/Points on me graciously with fair aspect

title: Sonnet XXVI
couplet: And puts apparel on my tatter'd loving,/To show me worthy of thy sweet respect:

title: Sonnet XXVI
couplet: Then may I dare to boast how I do love thee;/  Till then not show my head where thou mayst prove me.

title: Sonnet XXVII
couplet: Weary with toil, I haste me to my bed,/The dear repose for limbs with travel tired;

title: Sonnet XXVII
couplet: But then begins a journey in my head,/To work my mind, when body's work's expired:

title: Sonnet XXVII
couplet: For then my thoughts, from far where I abide,/Intend a zealous pilgrimage to thee,

title: Sonnet XXVII
couplet: And keep my drooping eyelids open wide,/Looking on darkness which the blind do see

title: Sonnet XXVII
couplet: Save that my soul's imaginary sight/Presents thy shadow to my sightless view,

title: Sonnet XXVII
couplet: Which, like a jewel hung in ghastly night,/Makes black night beauteous and her old face new.

title: Sonnet XXVII
couplet: Lo! thus, by day my limbs, by night my mind,/  For thee and for myself no quiet find.

title: Sonnet XXVIII
couplet: How can I then return in happy plight,/That am debarr'd the benefit of rest?

title: Sonnet XXVIII
couplet: When day's oppression is not eased by night,/But day by night, and night by day, oppress'd?

title: Sonnet XXVIII
couplet: And each, though enemies to either's reign,/Do in consent shake hands to torture me;

title: Sonnet XXVIII
couplet: The one by toil, the other to complain/How far I toil, still farther off from thee.

title: Sonnet XXVIII
couplet: I tell the day, to please them thou art bright/And dost him grace when clouds do blot the heaven:

title: Sonnet XXVIII
couplet: So flatter I the swart-complexion'd night,/When sparkling stars twire not thou gild'st the even.

title: Sonnet XXVIII
couplet: But day doth daily draw my sorrows longer/  And night doth nightly make grief's strength

title: Sonnet XXVIII
couplet: seem stronger./

title: Sonnet XXIX
couplet: When, in disgrace with fortune and men's eyes,/I all alone beweep my outcast state

title: Sonnet XXIX
couplet: And trouble deaf heaven with my bootless cries/And look upon myself and curse my fate,

title: Sonnet XXIX
couplet: Wishing me like to one more rich in hope,/Featured like him, like him with friends possess'd,

title: Sonnet XXIX
couplet: Desiring this man's art and that man's scope,/With what I most enjoy contented least;

title: Sonnet XXIX
couplet: Yet in these thoughts myself almost despising,/Haply I think on thee, and then my state,

title: Sonnet XXIX
couplet: Like to the lark at break of day arising/From sullen earth, sings hymns at heaven's gate;

title: Sonnet XXIX
couplet: For thy sweet love remember'd such wealth brings/  That then I scorn to change my state with kings.

title: Sonnet XXX
couplet: When to the sessions of sweet silent thought/I summon up remembrance of things past,

title: Sonnet XXX
couplet: I sigh the lack of many a thing I sought,/And with old woes new wail my dear time's waste:

title: Sonnet XXX
couplet: Then can I drown an eye, unused to flow,/For precious friends hid in death's dateless night,

title: Sonnet XXX
couplet: And weep afresh love's long since cancell'd woe,/And moan the expense of many a vanish'd sight:

title: Sonnet XXX
couplet: Then can I grieve at grievances foregone,/And heavily from woe to woe tell o'er

title: Sonnet XXX
couplet: The sad account of fore-bemoaned moan,/Which I new pay as if not paid before.

title: Sonnet XXX
couplet: But if the while I think on thee, dear friend,/  All losses are restored and sorrows end.

title: Sonnet XXXI
couplet: Thy bosom is endeared with all hearts,/Which I by lacking have supposed dead,

title: Sonnet XXXI
couplet: And there reigns love and all love's loving parts,/And all those friends which I thought buried.

title: Sonnet XXXI
couplet: How many a holy and obsequious tear/Hath dear religious love stol'n from mine eye

title: Sonnet XXXI
couplet: As interest of the dead, which now appear/But things removed that hidden in thee lie!

title: Sonnet XXXI
couplet: Thou art the grave where buried love doth live,/Hung with the trophies of my lovers gone,

title: Sonnet XXXI
couplet: Who all their parts of me to thee did give;/That due of many now is thine alone:

title: Sonnet XXXI
couplet: Their images I loved I view in thee,/  And thou, all they, hast all the all of me.

title: Sonnet XXXII
couplet: If thou survive my well-contented day,/When that churl Death my bones with dust shall cover,

title: Sonnet XXXII
couplet: And shalt by fortune once more re-survey/These poor rude lines of thy deceased lover,

title: Sonnet XXXII
couplet: Compare them with the bettering of the time,/And though they be outstripp'd by every pen,

title: Sonnet XXXII
couplet: Reserve them for my love, not for their rhyme,/Exceeded by the height of happier men.

title: Sonnet XXXII
couplet: O, then vouchsafe me but this loving thought:/'Had my friend's Muse grown with this growing age,

title: Sonnet XXXII
couplet: A dearer birth than this his love had brought,/To march in ranks of better equipage:

title: Sonnet XXXII
couplet: But since he died and poets better prove,/  Theirs for their style I'll read, his for his love.'

title: Sonnet XXXIII
couplet: Full many a glorious morning have I seen/Flatter the mountain-tops with sovereign eye,

title: Sonnet XXXIII
couplet: Kissing with golden face the meadows green,/Gilding pale streams with heavenly alchemy;

title: Sonnet XXXIII
couplet: Anon permit the basest clouds to ride/With ugly rack on his celestial face,

title: Sonnet XXXIII
couplet: And from the forlorn world his visage hide,/Stealing unseen to west with this disgrace:

title: Sonnet XXXIII
couplet: Even so my sun one early morn did shine/With all triumphant splendor on my brow;

title: Sonnet XXXIII
couplet: But out, alack! he was but one hour mine;/The region cloud hath mask'd him from me now.

title: Sonnet XXXIII
couplet: Yet him for this my love no whit disdaineth;/  Suns of the world may stain when heaven's sun staineth.

title: Sonnet XXXIV
couplet: Why didst thou promise such a beauteous day,/And make me travel forth without my cloak,

title: Sonnet XXXIV
couplet: To let base clouds o'ertake me in my way,/Hiding thy bravery in their rotten smoke?

title: Sonnet XXXIV
couplet: 'Tis not enough that through the cloud thou break,/To dry the rain on my storm-beaten face,

title: Sonnet XXXIV
couplet: For no man well of such a salve can speak/That heals the wound and cures not the disgrace:

title: Sonnet XXXIV
couplet: Nor can thy shame give physic to my grief;/Though thou repent, yet I have still the loss:

title: Sonnet XXXIV
couplet: The offender's sorrow lends but weak relief/To him that bears the strong offence's cross.

title: Sonnet XXXIV
couplet: Ah! but those tears are pearl which thy love sheds,/  And they are rich and ransom all ill deeds.

title: Sonnet XXXV
couplet: No more be grieved at that which thou hast done:/Roses have thorns, and silver fountains mud;

title: Sonnet XXXV
couplet: Clouds and eclipses stain both moon and sun,/And loathsome canker lives in sweetest bud.

title: Sonnet XXXV
couplet: All men make faults, and even I in this,/Authorizing thy trespass with compare,

title: Sonnet XXXV
couplet: Myself corrupting, salving thy amiss,/Excusing thy sins more than thy sins are;

title: Sonnet XXXV
couplet: For to thy sensual fault I bring in sense--/Thy adverse party is thy advocate--

title: Sonnet XXXV
couplet: And 'gainst myself a lawful plea commence:/Such civil war is in my love and hate

title: Sonnet XXXV
couplet: That I an accessary needs must be/  To that sweet thief which sourly robs from me.

title: Sonnet XXXVI
couplet: Let me confess that we two must be twain,/Although our undivided loves are one:

title: Sonnet XXXVI
couplet: So shall those blots that do with me remain/Without thy help by me be borne alone.

title: Sonnet XXXVI
couplet: In our two loves there is but one respect,/Though in our lives a separable spite,

title: Sonnet XXXVI
couplet: Which though it alter not love's sole effect,/Yet doth it steal sweet hours from love's delight.

title: Sonnet XXXVI
couplet: I may not evermore acknowledge thee,/Lest my bewailed guilt should do thee shame,

title: Sonnet XXXVI
couplet: Nor thou with public kindness honour me,/Unless thou take that honour from thy name:

title: Sonnet XXXVI
couplet: But do not so; I love thee in such sort/  As, thou being mine, mine is thy good report.

title: Sonnet XXXVII
couplet: As a decrepit father takes delight/To see his active child do deeds of youth,

title: Sonnet XXXVII
couplet: So I, made lame by fortune's dearest spite,/Take all my comfort of thy worth and truth.

title: Sonnet XXXVII
couplet: For whether beauty, birth, or wealth, or wit,/Or any of these all, or all, or more,

title: Sonnet XXXVII
couplet: Entitled in thy parts do crowned sit,/I make my love engrafted to this store:

title: Sonnet XXXVII
couplet: So then I am not lame, poor, nor despised,/Whilst that this shadow doth such substance give

title: Sonnet XXXVII
couplet: That I in thy abundance am sufficed/And by a part of all thy glory live.

title: Sonnet XXXVII
couplet: Look, what is best, that best I wish in thee:/  This wish I have; then ten times happy me!

title: Sonnet XXXVIII
couplet: How can my Muse want subject to invent,/While thou dost breathe, that pour'st into my verse

title: Sonnet XXXVIII
couplet: Thine own sweet argument, too excellent/For every vulgar paper to rehearse?

title: Sonnet XXXVIII
couplet: O, give thyself the thanks, if aught in me/Worthy perusal stand against thy sight;

title: Sonnet XXXVIII
couplet: For who's so dumb that cannot write to thee,/When thou thyself dost give invention light?

title: Sonnet XXXVIII
couplet: Be thou the tenth Muse, ten times more in worth/Than those old nine which rhymers invocate;

title: Sonnet XXXVIII
couplet: And he that calls on thee, let him bring forth/Eternal numbers to outlive long date.

title: Sonnet XXXVIII
couplet: If my slight Muse do please these curious days,/  The pain be mine, but thine shall be the praise.

title: Sonnet XXXIX
couplet: O, how thy worth with manners may I sing,/When thou art all the better part of me?

title: Sonnet XXXIX
couplet: What can mine own praise to mine own self bring?/And what is 't but mine own when I praise thee?

title: Sonnet XXXIX
couplet: Even for this let us divided live,/And our dear love lose name of single one,

title: Sonnet XXXIX
couplet: That by this separation I may give/That due to thee which thou deservest alone.

title: Sonnet XXXIX
couplet: O absence, what a torment wouldst thou prove,/Were it not thy sour leisure gave sweet leave

title: Sonnet XXXIX
couplet: To entertain the time with thoughts of love,/Which time and thoughts so sweetly doth deceive,

title: Sonnet XXXIX
couplet: And that thou teachest how to make one twain,/  By praising him here who doth hence remain!

title: Sonnet XL
couplet: Take all my loves, my love, yea, take them all;/What hast thou then more than thou hadst before?

title: Sonnet XL
couplet: No love, my love, that thou mayst true love call;/All mine was thine before thou hadst this more.

title: Sonnet XL
couplet: Then if for my love thou my love receivest,/I cannot blame thee for my love thou usest;

title: Sonnet XL
couplet: But yet be blamed, if thou thyself deceivest/By wilful taste of what thyself refusest.

title: Sonnet XL
couplet: I do forgive thy robbery, gentle thief,/Although thou steal thee all my poverty;

title: Sonnet XL
couplet: And yet, love knows, it is a greater grief/To bear love's wrong than hate's known injury.

title: Sonnet XL
couplet: Lascivious grace, in whom all ill well shows,/  Kill me with spites; yet we must not be foes.

title: Sonnet XLI
couplet: Those petty wrongs that liberty commits,/When I am sometime absent from thy heart,

title: Sonnet XLI
couplet: Thy beauty and thy years full well befits,/For still temptation follows where thou art.

title: Sonnet XLI
couplet: Gentle thou art and therefore to be won,/Beauteous thou art, therefore to be assailed;

title: Sonnet XLI
couplet: And when a woman woos, what woman's son/Will sourly leave her till she have prevailed?

title: Sonnet XLI
couplet: Ay me! but yet thou mightest my seat forbear,/And chide try beauty and thy straying youth,

title: Sonnet XLI
couplet: Who lead thee in their riot even there/Where thou art forced to break a twofold truth,

title: Sonnet XLI
couplet: Hers by thy beauty tempting her to thee,/  Thine, by thy beauty being false to me.

title: Sonnet XLII
couplet: That thou hast her, it is not all my grief,/And yet it may be said I loved her dearly;

title: Sonnet XLII
couplet: That she hath thee, is of my wailing chief,/A loss in love that touches me more nearly.

title: Sonnet XLII
couplet: Loving offenders, thus I will excuse ye:/Thou dost love her, because thou knowst I love her;

title: Sonnet XLII
couplet: And for my sake even so doth she abuse me,/Suffering my friend for my sake to approve her.

title: Sonnet XLII
couplet: If I lose thee, my loss is my love's gain,/And losing her, my friend hath found that loss;

title: Sonnet XLII
couplet: Both find each other, and I lose both twain,/And both for my sake lay on me this cross:

title: Sonnet XLII
couplet: But here's the joy; my friend and I are one;/  Sweet flattery! then she loves but me alone.

title: Sonnet XLIII
couplet: When most I wink, then do mine eyes best see,/For all the day they view things unrespected;

title: Sonnet XLIII
couplet: But when I sleep, in dreams they look on thee,/And darkly bright are bright in dark directed.

title: Sonnet XLIII
couplet: Then thou, whose shadow shadows doth make bright,/How would thy shadow's form form happy show

title: Sonnet XLIII
couplet: To the clear day with thy much clearer light,/When to unseeing eyes thy shade shines so!

title: Sonnet XLIII
couplet: How would, I say, mine eyes be blessed made/By looking on thee in the living day,

title: Sonnet XLIII
couplet: When in dead night thy fair imperfect shade/Through heavy sleep on sightless eyes doth stay!

title: Sonnet XLIII
couplet: All days are nights to see till I see thee,/  And nights bright days when dreams do show thee me.

title: Sonnet XLIV
couplet: If the dull substance of my flesh were thought,/Injurious distance should not stop my way;

title: Sonnet XLIV
couplet: For then despite of space I would be brought,/From limits far remote where thou dost stay.

title: Sonnet XLIV
couplet: No matter then although my foot did stand/Upon the farthest earth removed from thee;

title: Sonnet XLIV
couplet: For nimble thought can jump both sea and land/As soon as think the place where he would be.

title: Sonnet XLIV
couplet: But ah! thought kills me that I am not thought,/To leap large lengths of miles when thou art gone,

title: Sonnet XLIV
couplet: But that so much of earth and water wrought/I must attend time's leisure with my moan,

title: Sonnet XLIV
couplet: Receiving nought by elements so slow/  But heavy tears, badges of either's woe.

title: Sonnet XLV
couplet: The other two, slight air and purging fire,/Are both with thee, wherever I abide;

title: Sonnet XLV
couplet: The first my thought, the other my desire,/These present-absent with swift motion slide.

title: Sonnet XLV
couplet: For when these quicker elements are gone/In tender embassy of love to thee,

title: Sonnet XLV
couplet: My life, being made of four, with two alone/Sinks down to death, oppress'd with melancholy;

title: Sonnet XLV
couplet: Until life's composition be recured/By those swift messengers return'd from thee,

title: Sonnet XLV
couplet: Who even but now come back again, assured/Of thy fair health, recounting it to me:

title: Sonnet XLV
couplet: This told, I joy; but then no longer glad,/  I send them back again and straight grow sad.

title: Sonnet XLVI
couplet: Mine eye and heart are at a mortal war/How to divide the conquest of thy sight;

title: Sonnet XLVI
couplet: Mine eye my heart thy picture's sight would bar,/My heart mine eye the freedom of that right.

title: Sonnet XLVI
couplet: My heart doth plead that thou in him dost lie--/A closet never pierced with crystal eyes--

title: Sonnet XLVI
couplet: But the defendant doth that plea deny/And says in him thy fair appearance lies.

title: Sonnet XLVI
couplet: To 'cide this title is impanneled/A quest of thoughts, all tenants to the heart,

title: Sonnet XLVI
couplet: And by their verdict is determined/The clear eye's moiety and the dear heart's part:

title: Sonnet XLVI
couplet: As thus; mine eye's due is thy outward part,/  And my heart's right thy inward love of heart.

title: Sonnet XLVII
couplet: Betwixt mine eye and heart a league is took,/And each doth good turns now unto the other:

title: Sonnet XLVII
couplet: When that mine eye is famish'd for a look,/Or heart in love with sighs himself doth smother,

title: Sonnet XLVII
couplet: With my love's picture then my eye doth feast/And to the painted banquet bids my heart;

title: Sonnet XLVII
couplet: Another time mine eye is my heart's guest/And in his thoughts of love doth share a part:

title: Sonnet XLVII
couplet: So, either by thy picture or my love,/Thyself away art resent still with me;

title: Sonnet XLVII
couplet: For thou not farther than my thoughts canst move,/And I am still with them and they with thee;

title: Sonnet XLVII
couplet: Or, if they sleep, thy picture in my sight/  Awakes my heart to heart's and eye's delight.

title: Sonnet XLVIII
couplet: How careful was I, when I took my way,/Each trifle under truest bars to thrust,

title: Sonnet XLVIII
couplet: That to my use it might unused stay/From hands of falsehood, in sure wards of trust!

title: Sonnet XLVIII
couplet: But thou, to whom my jewels trifles are,/Most worthy of comfort, now my greatest grief,

title: Sonnet XLVIII
couplet: Thou, best of dearest and mine only care,/Art left the prey of every vulgar thief.

title: Sonnet XLVIII
couplet: Thee have I not lock'd up in any chest,/Save where thou art not, though I feel thou art,

title: Sonnet XLVIII
couplet: Within the gentle closure of my breast,/From whence at pleasure thou mayst come and part;

title: Sonnet XLVIII
couplet: And even thence thou wilt be stol'n, I fear,/  For truth proves thievish for a prize so dear.

title: Sonnet XLIX
couplet: Against that time, if ever that time come,/When I shall see thee frown on my defects,

title: Sonnet XLIX
couplet: When as thy love hath cast his utmost sum,/Call'd to that audit by advised respects;

title: Sonnet XLIX
couplet: Against that time when thou shalt strangely pass/And scarcely greet me with that sun thine eye,

title: Sonnet XLIX
couplet: When love, converted from the thing it was,/Shall reasons find of settled gravity,--

title: Sonnet XLIX
couplet: Against that time do I ensconce me here/Within the knowledge of mine own desert,

title: Sonnet XLIX
couplet: And this my hand against myself uprear,/To guard the lawful reasons on thy part:

title: Sonnet XLIX
couplet: To leave poor me thou hast the strength of laws,/  Since why to love I can allege no cause.

title: Sonnet L
couplet: How heavy do I journey on the way,/When what I seek, my weary travel's end,

title: Sonnet L
couplet: Doth teach that ease and that repose to say/'Thus far the miles are measured from thy friend!'

title: Sonnet L
couplet: The beast that bears me, tired with my woe,/Plods dully on, to bear that weight in me,

title: Sonnet L
couplet: As if by some instinct the wretch did know/His rider loved not speed, being made from thee:

title: Sonnet L
couplet: The bloody spur cannot provoke him on/That sometimes anger thrusts into his hide;

title: Sonnet L
couplet: Which heavily he answers with a groan,/More sharp to me than spurring to his side;

title: Sonnet L
couplet: For that same groan doth put this in my mind;/  My grief lies onward and my joy behind.

title: Sonnet LI
couplet: Thus can my love excuse the slow offence/Of my dull bearer when from thee I speed:

title: Sonnet LI
couplet: From where thou art why should I haste me thence?/Till I return, of posting is no need.

title: Sonnet LI
couplet: O, what excuse will my poor beast then find,/When swift extremity can seem but slow?

title: Sonnet LI
couplet: Then should I spur, though mounted on the wind;/In winged speed no motion shall I know:

title: Sonnet LI
couplet: Then can no horse with my desire keep pace;/Therefore desire of perfect'st love being made,

title: Sonnet LI
couplet: Shall neigh--no dull flesh--in his fiery race;/But love, for love, thus shall excuse my jade;

title: Sonnet LI
couplet: Since from thee going he went wilful-slow,/  Towards thee I'll run, and give him leave to go.

title: Sonnet LII
couplet: So am I as the rich, whose blessed key/Can bring him to his sweet up-locked treasure,

title: Sonnet LII
couplet: The which he will not every hour survey,/For blunting the fine point of seldom pleasure.

title: Sonnet LII
couplet: Therefore are feasts so solemn and so rare,/Since, seldom coming, in the long year set,

title: Sonnet LII
couplet: Like stones of worth they thinly placed are,/Or captain jewels in the carcanet.

title: Sonnet LII
couplet: So is the time that keeps you as my chest,/Or as the wardrobe which the robe doth hide,

title: Sonnet LII
couplet: To make some special instant special blest,/By new unfolding his imprison'd pride.

title: Sonnet LII
couplet: Blessed are you, whose worthiness gives scope,/  Being had, to triumph, being lack'd, to hope.

title: Sonnet LIII
couplet: What is your substance, whereof are you made,/That millions of strange shadows on you tend?

title: Sonnet LIII
couplet: Since every one hath, every one, one shade,/And you, but one, can every shadow lend.

title: Sonnet LIII
couplet: Describe Adonis, and the counterfeit/Is poorly imitated after you;

title: Sonnet LIII
couplet: On Helen's cheek all art of beauty set,/And you in Grecian tires are painted new:

title: Sonnet LIII
couplet: Speak of the spring and foison of the year;/The one doth shadow of your beauty show,

title: Sonnet LIII
couplet: The other as your bounty doth appear;/And you in every blessed shape we know.

title: Sonnet LIII
couplet: In all external grace you have some part,/  But you like none, none you, for constant heart.

title: Sonnet LIV
couplet: O, how much more doth beauty beauteous seem/By that sweet ornament which truth doth give!

title: Sonnet LIV
couplet: The rose looks fair, but fairer we it deem/For that sweet odour which doth in it live.

title: Sonnet LIV
couplet: The canker-blooms have full as deep a dye/As the perfumed tincture of the roses,

title: Sonnet LIV
couplet: Hang on such thorns and play as wantonly/When summer's breath their masked buds discloses:

title: Sonnet LIV
couplet: But, for their virtue only is their show,/They live unwoo'd and unrespected fade,

title: Sonnet LIV
couplet: Die to themselves. Sweet roses do not so;/Of their sweet deaths are sweetest odours made:

title: Sonnet LIV
couplet: And so of you, beauteous and lovely youth,/  When that shall fade, my verse distills your truth.

title: Sonnet LV
couplet: Not marble, nor the gilded monuments/Of princes, shall outlive this powerful rhyme;

title: Sonnet LV
couplet: But you shall shine more bright in these contents/Than unswept stone besmear'd with sluttish time.

title: Sonnet LV
couplet: When wasteful war shall statues overturn,/And broils root out the work of masonry,

title: Sonnet LV
couplet: Nor Mars his sword nor war's quick fire shall burn/The living record of your memory.

title: Sonnet LV
couplet: 'Gainst death and all-oblivious enmity/Shall you pace forth; your praise shall still find room

title: Sonnet LV
couplet: Even in the eyes of all posterity/That wear this world out to the ending doom.

title: Sonnet LV
couplet: So, till the judgment that yourself arise,/  You live in this, and dwell in lover's eyes.

title: Sonnet LVI
couplet: Sweet love, renew thy force; be it not said/Thy edge should blunter be than appetite,

title: Sonnet LVI
couplet: Which but to-day by feeding is allay'd,/To-morrow sharpen'd in his former might:

title: Sonnet LVI
couplet: So, love, be thou; although to-day thou fill/Thy hungry eyes even till they wink with fullness,

title: Sonnet LVI
couplet: To-morrow see again, and do not kill/The spirit of love with a perpetual dullness.

title: Sonnet LVI
couplet: Let this sad interim like the ocean be/Which parts the shore, where two contracted new

title: Sonnet LVI
couplet: Come daily to the banks, that, when they see/Return of love, more blest may be the view;

title: Sonnet LVI
couplet: Else call it winter, which being full of care/  Makes summer's welcome thrice more wish'd, more rare.

title: Sonnet LVII
couplet: Being your slave, what should I do but tend/Upon the hours and times of your desire?

title: Sonnet LVII
couplet: I have no precious time at all to spend,/Nor services to do, till you require.

title: Sonnet LVII
couplet: Nor dare I chide the world-without-end hour/Whilst I, my sovereign, watch the clock for you,

title: Sonnet LVII
couplet: Nor think the bitterness of absence sour/When you have bid your servant once adieu;

title: Sonnet LVII
couplet: Nor dare I question with my jealous thought/Where you may be, or your affairs suppose,

title: Sonnet LVII
couplet: But, like a sad slave, stay and think of nought/Save, where you are how happy you make those.

title: Sonnet LVII
couplet: So true a fool is love that in your will,/  Though you do any thing, he thinks no ill.

title: Sonnet LVIII
couplet: That god forbid that made me first your slave,/I should in thought control your times of pleasure,

title: Sonnet LVIII
couplet: Or at your hand the account of hours to crave,/Being your vassal, bound to stay your leisure!

title: Sonnet LVIII
couplet: O, let me suffer, being at your beck,/The imprison'd absence of your liberty;

title: Sonnet LVIII
couplet: And patience, tame to sufferance, bide each cheque,/Without accusing you of injury.

title: Sonnet LVIII
couplet: Be where you list, your charter is so strong/That you yourself may privilege your time

title: Sonnet LVIII
couplet: To what you will; to you it doth belong/Yourself to pardon of self-doing crime.

title: Sonnet LVIII
couplet: I am to wait, though waiting so be hell;/  Not blame your pleasure, be it ill or well.

title: Sonnet LIX
couplet: If there be nothing new, but that which is/Hath been before, how are our brains beguiled,

title: Sonnet LIX
couplet: Which, labouring for invention, bear amiss/The second burden of a former child!

title: Sonnet LIX
couplet: O, that record could with a backward look,/Even of five hundred courses of the sun,

title: Sonnet LIX
couplet: Show me your image in some antique book,/Since mind at first in character was done!

title: Sonnet LIX
couplet: That I might see what the old world could say/To this composed wonder of your frame;

title: Sonnet LIX
couplet: Whether we are mended, or whether better they,/Or whether revolution be the same.

title: Sonnet LIX
couplet: O, sure I am, the wits of former days/  To subjects worse have given admiring praise.

title: Sonnet LX
couplet: Like as the waves make towards the pebbled shore,/So do our minutes hasten to their end;

title: Sonnet LX
couplet: Each changing place with that which goes before,/In sequent toil all forwards do contend.

title: Sonnet LX
couplet: Nativity, once in the main of light,/Crawls to maturity, wherewith being crown'd,

title: Sonnet LX
couplet: Crooked elipses 'gainst his glory fight,/And Time that gave doth now his gift confound.

title: Sonnet LX
couplet: Time doth transfix the flourish set on youth/And delves the parallels in beauty's brow,

title: Sonnet LX
couplet: Feeds on the rarities of nature's truth,/And nothing stands but for his scythe to mow:

title: Sonnet LX
couplet: And yet to times in hope my verse shall stand,/  Praising thy worth, despite his cruel hand.

title: Sonnet LXI
couplet: Is it thy will thy image should keep open/My heavy eyelids to the weary night?

title: Sonnet LXI
couplet: Dost thou desire my slumbers should be broken,/While shadows like to thee do mock my sight?

title: Sonnet LXI
couplet: Is it thy spirit that thou send'st from thee/So far from home into my deeds to pry,

title: Sonnet LXI
couplet: To find out shames and idle hours in me,/The scope and tenor of thy jealousy?

title: Sonnet LXI
couplet: O, no! thy love, though much, is not so great:/It is my love that keeps mine eye awake;

title: Sonnet LXI
couplet: Mine own true love that doth my rest defeat,/To play the watchman ever for thy sake:

title: Sonnet LXI
couplet: For thee watch I whilst thou dost wake elsewhere,/  From me far off, with others all too near.

title: Sonnet LXII
couplet: Sin of self-love possesseth all mine eye/And all my soul and all my every part;

title: Sonnet LXII
couplet: And for this sin there is no remedy,/It is so grounded inward in my heart.

title: Sonnet LXII
couplet: Methinks no face so gracious is as mine,/No shape so true, no truth of such account;

title: Sonnet LXII
couplet: And for myself mine own worth do define,/As I all other in all worths surmount.

title: Sonnet LXII
couplet: But when my glass shows me myself indeed,/Beated and chopp'd with tann'd antiquity,

title: Sonnet LXII
couplet: Mine own self-love quite contrary I read;/Self so self-loving were iniquity.

title: Sonnet LXII
couplet: 'Tis thee, myself, that for myself I praise,/  Painting my age with beauty of thy days.

title: Sonnet LXIII
couplet: Against my love shall be, as I am now,/With Time's injurious hand crush'd and o'er-worn;

title: Sonnet LXIII
couplet: When hours have drain'd his blood and fill'd his brow/With lines and wrinkles; when his youthful morn

title: Sonnet LXIII
couplet: Hath travell'd on to age's steepy night,/And all those beauties whereof now he's king

title: Sonnet LXIII
couplet: Are vanishing or vanish'd out of sight,/Stealing away the treasure of his spring;

title: Sonnet LXIII
couplet: For such a time do I now fortify/Against confounding age's cruel knife,

title: Sonnet LXIII
couplet: That he shall never cut from memory/My sweet love's beauty, though my lover's life:

title: Sonnet LXIII
couplet: His beauty shall in these black lines be seen,/  And they shall live, and he in them still green.

title: Sonnet LXIV
couplet: When I have seen by Time's fell hand defaced/The rich proud cost of outworn buried age;

title: Sonnet LXIV
couplet: When sometime lofty towers I see down-razed/And brass eternal slave to mortal rage;

title: Sonnet LXIV
couplet: When I have seen the hungry ocean gain/Advantage on the kingdom of the shore,

title: Sonnet LXIV
couplet: And the firm soil win of the watery main,/Increasing store with loss and loss with store;

title: Sonnet LXIV
couplet: When I have seen such interchange of state,/Or state itself confounded to decay;

title: Sonnet LXIV
couplet: Ruin hath taught me thus to ruminate,/That Time will come and take my love away.

title: Sonnet LXIV
couplet: This thought is as a death, which cannot choose/  But weep to have that which it fears to lose.

title: Sonnet LXV
couplet: Since brass, nor stone, nor earth, nor boundless sea,/But sad mortality o'er-sways their power,

title: Sonnet LXV
couplet: How with this rage shall beauty hold a plea,/Whose action is no stronger than a flower?

title: Sonnet LXV
couplet: O, how shall summer's honey breath hold out/Against the wreckful siege of battering days,

title: Sonnet LXV
couplet: When rocks impregnable are not so stout,/Nor gates of steel so strong, but Time decays?

title: Sonnet LXV
couplet: O fearful meditation! where, alack,/Shall Time's best jewel from Time's chest lie hid?

title: Sonnet LXV
couplet: Or what strong hand can hold his swift foot back?/Or who his spoil of beauty can forbid?

title: Sonnet LXV
couplet: O, none, unless this miracle have might,/  That in black ink my love may still shine bright.

title: Sonnet LXVI
couplet: Tired with all these, for restful death I cry,/As, to behold desert a beggar born,

title: Sonnet LXVI
couplet: And needy nothing trimm'd in jollity,/And purest faith unhappily forsworn,

title: Sonnet LXVI
couplet: And guilded honour shamefully misplaced,/And maiden virtue rudely strumpeted,

title: Sonnet LXVI
couplet: And right perfection wrongfully disgraced,/And strength by limping sway disabled,

title: Sonnet LXVI
couplet: And art made tongue-tied by authority,/And folly doctor-like controlling skill,

title: Sonnet LXVI
couplet: And simple truth miscall'd simplicity,/And captive good attending captain ill:

title: Sonnet LXVI
couplet: Tired with all these, from these would I be gone,/  Save that, to die, I leave my love alone.

title: Sonnet LXVII
couplet: Ah! wherefore with infection should he live,/And with his presence grace impiety,

title: Sonnet LXVII
couplet: That sin by him advantage should achieve/And lace itself with his society?

title: Sonnet LXVII
couplet: Why should false painting imitate his cheek/And steal dead seeing of his living hue?

title: Sonnet LXVII
couplet: Why should poor beauty indirectly seek/Roses of shadow, since his rose is true?

title: Sonnet LXVII
couplet: Why should he live, now Nature bankrupt is,/Beggar'd of blood to blush through lively veins?

title: Sonnet LXVII
couplet: For she hath no exchequer now but his,/And, proud of many, lives upon his gains.

title: Sonnet LXVII
couplet: O, him she stores, to show what wealth she had/  In days long since, before these last so bad.

title: Sonnet LXVIII
couplet: Thus is his cheek the map of days outworn,/When beauty lived and died as flowers do now,

title: Sonnet LXVIII
couplet: Before the bastard signs of fair were born,/Or durst inhabit on a living brow;

title: Sonnet LXVIII
couplet: Before the golden tresses of the dead,/The right of sepulchres, were shorn away,

title: Sonnet LXVIII
couplet: To live a second life on second head;/Ere beauty's dead fleece made another gay:

title: Sonnet LXVIII
couplet: In him those holy antique hours are seen,/Without all ornament, itself and true,

title: Sonnet LXVIII
couplet: Making no summer of another's green,/Robbing no old to dress his beauty new;

title: Sonnet LXVIII
couplet: And him as for a map doth Nature store,/  To show false Art what beauty was of yore.

title: Sonnet LXIX
couplet: Those parts of thee that the world's eye doth view/Want nothing that the thought of hearts can mend;

title: Sonnet LXIX
couplet: All tongues, the voice of souls, give thee that due,/Uttering bare truth, even so as foes commend.

title: Sonnet LXIX
couplet: Thy outward thus with outward praise is crown'd;/But those same tongues that give thee so thine own

title: Sonnet LXIX
couplet: In other accents do this praise confound/By seeing farther than the eye hath shown.

title: Sonnet LXIX
couplet: They look into the beauty of thy mind,/And that, in guess, they measure by thy deeds;

title: Sonnet LXIX
couplet: Then, churls, their thoughts, although their eyes were kind,/To thy fair flower add the rank smell of weeds:

title: Sonnet LXIX
couplet: But why thy odour matcheth not thy show,/  The solve is this, that thou dost common grow.

title: Sonnet LXX
couplet: That thou art blamed shall not be thy defect,/For slander's mark was ever yet the fair;

title: Sonnet LXX
couplet: The ornament of beauty is suspect,/A crow that flies in heaven's sweetest air.

title: Sonnet LXX
couplet: So thou be good, slander doth but approve/Thy worth the greater, being woo'd of time;

title: Sonnet LXX
couplet: For canker vice the sweetest buds doth love,/And thou present'st a pure unstained prime.

title: Sonnet LXX
couplet: Thou hast pass'd by the ambush of young days,/Either not assail'd or victor being charged;

title: Sonnet LXX
couplet: Yet this thy praise cannot be so thy praise,/To tie up envy evermore enlarged:

title: Sonnet LXX
couplet: If some suspect of ill mask'd not thy show,/  Then thou alone kingdoms of hearts shouldst owe.

title: Sonnet LXXI
couplet: No longer mourn for me when I am dead/Then you shall hear the surly sullen bell

title: Sonnet LXXI
couplet: Give warning to the world that I am fled/From this vile world, with vilest worms to dwell:

title: Sonnet LXXI
couplet: Nay, if you read this line, remember not/The hand that writ it; for I love you so

title: Sonnet LXXI
couplet: That I in your sweet thoughts would be forgot/If thinking on me then should make you woe.

title: Sonnet LXXI
couplet: O, if, I say, you look upon this verse/When I perhaps compounded am with clay,

title: Sonnet LXXI
couplet: Do not so much as my poor name rehearse./But let your love even with my life decay,

title: Sonnet LXXI
couplet: Lest the wise world should look into your moan/  And mock you with me after I am gone.

title: Sonnet LXXII
couplet: O, lest the world should task you to recite/What merit lived in me, that you should love

title: Sonnet LXXII
couplet: After my death, dear love, forget me quite,/For you in me can nothing worthy prove;

title: Sonnet LXXII
couplet: Unless you would devise some virtuous lie,/To do more for me than mine own desert,

title: Sonnet LXXII
couplet: And hang more praise upon deceased I/Than niggard truth would willingly impart:

title: Sonnet LXXII
couplet: O, lest your true love may seem false in this,/That you for love speak well of me untrue,

title: Sonnet LXXII
couplet: My name be buried where my body is,/And live no more to shame nor me nor you.

title: Sonnet LXXII
couplet: For I am shamed by that which I bring forth,/  And so should you, to love things nothing worth.

title: Sonnet LXXIII
couplet: That time of year thou mayst in me behold/When yellow leaves, or none, or few, do hang

title: Sonnet LXXIII
couplet: Upon those boughs which shake against the cold,/Bare ruin'd choirs, where late the sweet birds sang.

title: Sonnet LXXIII
couplet: In me thou seest the twilight of such day/As after sunset fadeth in the west,

title: Sonnet LXXIII
couplet: Which by and by black night doth take away,/Death's second self, that seals up all in rest.

title: Sonnet LXXIII
couplet: In me thou see'st the glowing of such fire/That on the ashes of his youth doth lie,

title: Sonnet LXXIII
couplet: As the death-bed whereon it must expire/Consumed with that which it was nourish'd by.

title: Sonnet LXXIII
couplet: This thou perceivest, which makes thy love more strong,/  To love that well which thou must leave ere long.

title: Sonnet LXXIV
couplet: But be contented: when that fell arrest/Without all bail shall carry me away,

title: Sonnet LXXIV
couplet: My life hath in this line some interest,/Which for memorial still with thee shall stay.

title: Sonnet LXXIV
couplet: When thou reviewest this, thou dost review/The very part was consecrate to thee:

title: Sonnet LXXIV
couplet: The earth can have but earth, which is his due;/My spirit is thine, the better part of me:

title: Sonnet LXXIV
couplet: So then thou hast but lost the dregs of life,/The prey of worms, my body being dead,

title: Sonnet LXXIV
couplet: The coward conquest of a wretch's knife,/Too base of thee to be remembered.

title: Sonnet LXXIV
couplet: The worth of that is that which it contains,/  And that is this, and this with thee remains.

title: Sonnet LXXV
couplet: So are you to my thoughts as food to life,/Or as sweet-season'd showers are to the ground;

title: Sonnet LXXV
couplet: And for the peace of you I hold such strife/As 'twixt a miser and his wealth is found;

title: Sonnet LXXV
couplet: Now proud as an enjoyer and anon/Doubting the filching age will steal his treasure,

title: Sonnet LXXV
couplet: Now counting best to be with you alone,/Then better'd that the world may see my pleasure;

title: Sonnet LXXV
couplet: Sometime all full with feasting on your sight/And by and by clean starved for a look;

title: Sonnet LXXV
couplet: Possessing or pursuing no delight,/Save what is had or must from you be took.

title: Sonnet LXXV
couplet: Thus do I pine and surfeit day by day,/  Or gluttoning on all, or all away.

title: Sonnet LXXVI
couplet: Why is my verse so barren of new pride,/So far from variation or quick change?

title: Sonnet LXXVI
couplet: Why with the time do I not glance aside/To new-found methods and to compounds strange?

title: Sonnet LXXVI
couplet: Why write I still all one, ever the same,/And keep invention in a noted weed,

title: Sonnet LXXVI
couplet: That every word doth almost tell my name,/Showing their birth and where they did proceed?

title: Sonnet LXXVI
couplet: O, know, sweet love, I always write of you,/And you and love are still my argument;

title: Sonnet LXXVI
couplet: So all my best is dressing old words new,/Spending again what is already spent:

title: Sonnet LXXVI
couplet: For as the sun is daily new and old,/  So is my love still telling what is told.

title: Sonnet LXXVII
couplet: Thy glass will show thee how thy beauties wear,/Thy dial how thy precious minutes waste;

title: Sonnet LXXVII
couplet: The vacant leaves thy mind's imprint will bear,/And of this book this learning mayst thou taste.

title: Sonnet LXXVII
couplet: The wrinkles which thy glass will truly show/Of mouthed graves will give thee memory;

title: Sonnet LXXVII
couplet: Thou by thy dial's shady stealth mayst know/Time's thievish progress to eternity.

title: Sonnet LXXVII
couplet: Look, what thy memory can not contain/Commit to these waste blanks, and thou shalt find

title: Sonnet LXXVII
couplet: Those children nursed, deliver'd from thy brain,/To take a new acquaintance of thy mind.

title: Sonnet LXXVII
couplet: These offices, so oft as thou wilt look,/  Shall profit thee and much enrich thy book.

title: Sonnet LXXVIII
couplet: So oft have I invoked thee for my Muse/And found such fair assistance in my verse

title: Sonnet LXXVIII
couplet: As every alien pen hath got my use/And under thee their poesy disperse.

title: Sonnet LXXVIII
couplet: Thine eyes that taught the dumb on high to sing/And heavy ignorance aloft to fly

title: Sonnet LXXVIII
couplet: Have added feathers to the learned's wing/And given grace a double majesty.

title: Sonnet LXXVIII
couplet: Yet be most proud of that which I compile,/Whose influence is thine and born of thee:

title: Sonnet LXXVIII
couplet: In others' works thou dost but mend the style,/And arts with thy sweet graces graced be;

title: Sonnet LXXVIII
couplet: But thou art all my art and dost advance/  As high as learning my rude ignorance.

title: Sonnet LXXIX
couplet: Whilst I alone did call upon thy aid,/My verse alone had all thy gentle grace,

title: Sonnet LXXIX
couplet: But now my gracious numbers are decay'd/And my sick Muse doth give another place.

title: Sonnet LXXIX
couplet: I grant, sweet love, thy lovely argument/Deserves the travail of a worthier pen,

title: Sonnet LXXIX
couplet: Yet what of thee thy poet doth invent/He robs thee of and pays it thee again.

title: Sonnet LXXIX
couplet: He lends thee virtue and he stole that word/From thy behavior; beauty doth he give

title: Sonnet LXXIX
couplet: And found it in thy cheek; he can afford/No praise to thee but what in thee doth live.

title: Sonnet LXXIX
couplet: Then thank him not for that which he doth say,/  Since what he owes thee thou thyself dost pay.

title: Sonnet LXXX
couplet: O, how I faint when I of you do write,/Knowing a better spirit doth use your name,

title: Sonnet LXXX
couplet: And in the praise thereof spends all his might,/To make me tongue-tied, speaking of your fame!

title: Sonnet LXXX
couplet: But since your worth, wide as the ocean is,/The humble as the proudest sail doth bear,

title: Sonnet LXXX
couplet: My saucy bark inferior far to his/On your broad main doth wilfully appear.

title: Sonnet LXXX
couplet: Your shallowest help will hold me up afloat,/Whilst he upon your soundless deep doth ride;

title: Sonnet LXXX
couplet: Or being wreck'd, I am a worthless boat,/He of tall building and of goodly pride:

title: Sonnet LXXX
couplet: Then if he thrive and I be cast away,/  The worst was this; my love was my decay.

title: Sonnet LXXXI
couplet: Or I shall live your epitaph to make,/Or you survive when I in earth am rotten;

title: Sonnet LXXXI
couplet: From hence your memory death cannot take,/Although in me each part will be forgotten.

title: Sonnet LXXXI
couplet: Your name from hence immortal life shall have,/Though I, once gone, to all the world must die:

title: Sonnet LXXXI
couplet: The earth can yield me but a common grave,/When you entombed in men's eyes shall lie.

title: Sonnet LXXXI
couplet: Your monument shall be my gentle verse,/Which eyes not yet created shall o'er-read,

title: Sonnet LXXXI
couplet: And tongues to be your being shall rehearse/When all the breathers of this world are dead;

title: Sonnet LXXXI
couplet: You still shall live--such virtue hath my pen--/  Where breath most breathes, even in the mouths of men.

title: Sonnet LXXXII
couplet: I grant thou wert not married to my Muse/And therefore mayst without attaint o'erlook

title: Sonnet LXXXII
couplet: The dedicated words which writers use/Of their fair subject, blessing every book

title: Sonnet LXXXII
couplet: Thou art as fair in knowledge as in hue,/Finding thy worth a limit past my praise,

title: Sonnet LXXXII
couplet: And therefore art enforced to seek anew/Some fresher stamp of the time-bettering days

title: Sonnet LXXXII
couplet: And do so, love; yet when they have devised/What strained touches rhetoric can lend,

title: Sonnet LXXXII
couplet: Thou truly fair wert truly sympathized/In true plain words by thy true-telling friend;

title: Sonnet LXXXII
couplet: And their gross painting might be better used/  Where cheeks need blood; in thee it is abused.

title: Sonnet LXXXIII
couplet: I never saw that you did painting need/And therefore to your fair no painting set;

title: Sonnet LXXXIII
couplet: I found, or thought I found, you did exceed/The barren tender of a poet's debt;

title: Sonnet LXXXIII
couplet: And therefore have I slept in your report,/That you yourself being extant well might show

title: Sonnet LXXXIII
couplet: How far a modern quill doth come too short,/Speaking of worth, what worth in you doth grow.

title: Sonnet LXXXIII
couplet: This silence for my sin you did impute,/Which shall be most my glory, being dumb;

title: Sonnet LXXXIII
couplet: For I impair not beauty being mute,/When others would give life and bring a tomb.

title: Sonnet LXXXIII
couplet: There lives more life in one of your fair eyes/  Than both your poets can in praise devise.

title: Sonnet LXXXIV
couplet: Who is it that says most? which can say more/Than this rich praise, that you alone are you?

title: Sonnet LXXXIV
couplet: In whose confine immured is the store/Which should example where your equal grew.

title: Sonnet LXXXIV
couplet: Lean penury within that pen doth dwell/That to his subject lends not some small glory;

title: Sonnet LXXXIV
couplet: But he that writes of you, if he can tell/That you are you, so dignifies his story,

title: Sonnet LXXXIV
couplet: Let him but copy what in you is writ,/Not making worse what nature made so clear,

title: Sonnet LXXXIV
couplet: And such a counterpart shall fame his wit,/Making his style admired every where.

title: Sonnet LXXXIV
couplet: You to your beauteous blessings add a curse,/  Being fond on praise, which makes your praises worse.

title: Sonnet LXXXV
couplet: My tongue-tied Muse in manners holds her still,/While comments of your praise, richly compiled,

title: Sonnet LXXXV
couplet: Reserve their character with golden quill/And precious phrase by all the Muses filed.

title: Sonnet LXXXV
couplet: I think good thoughts whilst other write good words,/And like unletter'd clerk still cry 'Amen'

title: Sonnet LXXXV
couplet: To every hymn that able spirit affords/In polish'd form of well-refined pen.

title: Sonnet LXXXV
couplet: Hearing you praised, I say ''Tis so, 'tis true,'/And to the most of praise add something more;

title: Sonnet LXXXV
couplet: But that is in my thought, whose love to you,/Though words come hindmost, holds his rank before.

title: Sonnet LXXXV
couplet: Then others for the breath of words respect,/  Me for my dumb thoughts, speaking in effect.

title: Sonnet LXXXVI
couplet: Was it the proud full sail of his great verse,/Bound for the prize of all too precious you,

title: Sonnet LXXXVI
couplet: That did my ripe thoughts in my brain inhearse,/Making their tomb the womb wherein they grew?

title: Sonnet LXXXVI
couplet: Was it his spirit, by spirits taught to write/Above a mortal pitch, that struck me dead?

title: Sonnet LXXXVI
couplet: No, neither he, nor his compeers by night/Giving him aid, my verse astonished.

title: Sonnet LXXXVI
couplet: He, nor that affable familiar ghost/Which nightly gulls him with intelligence

title: Sonnet LXXXVI
couplet: As victors of my silence cannot boast;/I was not sick of any fear from thence:

title: Sonnet LXXXVI
couplet: But when your countenance fill'd up his line,/  Then lack'd I matter; that enfeebled mine.

title: Sonnet LXXXVII
couplet: Farewell! thou art too dear for my possessing,/And like enough thou know'st thy estimate:

title: Sonnet LXXXVII
couplet: The charter of thy worth gives thee releasing;/My bonds in thee are all determinate.

title: Sonnet LXXXVII
couplet: For how do I hold thee but by thy granting?/And for that riches where is my deserving?

title: Sonnet LXXXVII
couplet: The cause of this fair gift in me is wanting,/And so my patent back again is swerving.

title: Sonnet LXXXVII
couplet: Thyself thou gavest, thy own worth then not knowing,/Or me, to whom thou gavest it, else mistaking;

title: Sonnet LXXXVII
couplet: So thy great gift, upon misprision growing,/Comes home again, on better judgment making.

title: Sonnet LXXXVII
couplet: Thus have I had thee, as a dream doth flatter,/  In sleep a king, but waking no such matter.

title: Sonnet LXXXVIII
couplet: When thou shalt be disposed to set me light,/And place my merit in the eye of scorn,

title: Sonnet LXXXVIII
couplet: Upon thy side against myself I'll fight,/And prove thee virtuous, though thou art forsworn.

title: Sonnet LXXXVIII
couplet: With mine own weakness being best acquainted,/Upon thy part I can set down a story

title: Sonnet LXXXVIII
couplet: Of faults conceal'd, wherein I am attainted,/That thou in losing me shalt win much glory:

title: Sonnet LXXXVIII
couplet: And I by this will be a gainer too;/For bending all my loving thoughts on thee,

title: Sonnet LXXXVIII
couplet: The injuries that to myself I do,/Doing thee vantage, double-vantage me.

title: Sonnet LXXXVIII
couplet: Such is my love, to thee I so belong,/  That for thy right myself will bear all wrong.

title: Sonnet LXXXIX
couplet: Say that thou didst forsake me for some fault,/And I will comment upon that offence;

title: Sonnet LXXXIX
couplet: Speak of my lameness, and I straight will halt,/Against thy reasons making no defence.

title: Sonnet LXXXIX
couplet: Thou canst not, love, disgrace me half so ill,/To set a form upon desired change,

title: Sonnet LXXXIX
couplet: As I'll myself disgrace: knowing thy will,/I will acquaintance strangle and look strange,

title: Sonnet LXXXIX
couplet: Be absent from thy walks, and in my tongue/Thy sweet beloved name no more shall dwell,

title: Sonnet LXXXIX
couplet: Lest I, too much profane, should do it wrong/And haply of our old acquaintance tell.

title: Sonnet LXXXIX
couplet: For thee against myself I'll vow debate,/  For I must ne'er love him whom thou dost hate.

title: Sonnet XC
couplet: Then hate me when thou wilt; if ever, now;/Now, while the world is bent my deeds to cross,

title: Sonnet XC
couplet: Join with the spite of fortune, make me bow,/And do not drop in for an after-loss:

title: Sonnet XC
couplet: Ah, do not, when my heart hath 'scoped this sorrow,/Come in the rearward of a conquer'd woe;

title: Sonnet XC
couplet: Give not a windy night a rainy morrow,/To linger out a purposed overthrow.

title: Sonnet XC
couplet: If thou wilt leave me, do not leave me last,/When other petty griefs have done their spite

title: Sonnet XC
couplet: But in the onset come; so shall I taste/At first the very worst of fortune's might,

title: Sonnet XC
couplet: And other strains of woe, which now seem woe,/  Compared with loss of thee will not seem so.

title: Sonnet XCI
couplet: Some glory in their birth, some in their skill,/Some in their wealth, some in their bodies' force,

title: Sonnet XCI
couplet: Some in their garments, though new-fangled ill,/Some in their hawks and hounds, some in their horse;

title: Sonnet XCI
couplet: And every humour hath his adjunct pleasure,/Wherein it finds a joy above the rest:

title: Sonnet XCI
couplet: But these particulars are not my measure;/All these I better in one general best.

title: Sonnet XCI
couplet: Thy love is better than high birth to me,/Richer than wealth, prouder than garments' cost,

title: Sonnet XCI
couplet: Of more delight than hawks or horses be;/And having thee, of all men's pride I boast:

title: Sonnet XCI
couplet: Wretched in this alone, that thou mayst take/  All this away and me most wretched make.

title: Sonnet XCII
couplet: But do thy worst to steal thyself away,/For term of life thou art assured mine,

title: Sonnet XCII
couplet: And life no longer than thy love will stay,/For it depends upon that love of thine.

title: Sonnet XCII
couplet: Then need I not to fear the worst of wrongs,/When in the least of them my life hath end.

title: Sonnet XCII
couplet: I see a better state to me belongs/Than that which on thy humour doth depend;

title: Sonnet XCII
couplet: Thou canst not vex me with inconstant mind,/Since that my life on thy revolt doth lie.

title: Sonnet XCII
couplet: O, what a happy title do I find,/Happy to have thy love, happy to die!

title: Sonnet XCII
couplet: But what's so blessed-fair that fears no blot?/  Thou mayst be false, and yet I know it not.

title: Sonnet XCIII
couplet: So shall I live, supposing thou art true,/Like a deceived husband; so love's face

title: Sonnet XCIII
couplet: May still seem love to me, though alter'd new;/Thy looks with me, thy heart in other place:

title: Sonnet XCIII
couplet: For there can live no hatred in thine eye,/Therefore in that I cannot know thy change.

title: Sonnet XCIII
couplet: In many's looks the false heart's history/Is writ in moods and frowns and wrinkles strange,

title: Sonnet XCIII
couplet: But heaven in thy creation did decree/That in thy face sweet love should ever dwell;

title: Sonnet XCIII
couplet: Whate'er thy thoughts or thy heart's workings be,/Thy looks should nothing thence but sweetness tell.

title: Sonnet XCIII
couplet: How like Eve's apple doth thy beauty grow,/  if thy sweet virtue answer not thy show!

title: Sonnet XCIV
couplet: They that have power to hurt and will do none,/That do not do the thing they most do show,

title: Sonnet XCIV
couplet: Who, moving others, are themselves as stone,/Unmoved, cold, and to temptation slow,

title: Sonnet XCIV
couplet: They rightly do inherit heaven's graces/And husband nature's riches from expense;

title: Sonnet XCIV
couplet: They are the lords and owners of their faces,/Others but stewards of their excellence.

title: Sonnet XCIV
couplet: The summer's flower is to the summer sweet,/Though to itself it only live and die,

title: Sonnet XCIV
couplet: But if that flower with base infection meet,/The basest weed outbraves his dignity:

title: Sonnet XCIV
couplet: For sweetest things turn sourest by their deeds;/  Lilies that fester smell far worse than weeds.

title: Sonnet XCV
couplet: How sweet and lovely dost thou make the shame/Which, like a canker in the fragrant rose,

title: Sonnet XCV
couplet: Doth spot the beauty of thy budding name!/O, in what sweets dost thou thy sins enclose!

title: Sonnet XCV
couplet: That tongue that tells the story of thy days,/Making lascivious comments on thy sport,

title: Sonnet XCV
couplet: Cannot dispraise but in a kind of praise;/Naming thy name blesses an ill report.

title: Sonnet XCV
couplet: O, what a mansion have those vices got/Which for their habitation chose out thee,

title: Sonnet XCV
couplet: Where beauty's veil doth cover every blot,/And all things turn to fair that eyes can see!

title: Sonnet XCV
couplet: Take heed, dear heart, of this large privilege;/  The hardest knife ill-used doth lose his edge.

title: Sonnet XCVI
couplet: Some say thy fault is youth, some wantonness;/Some say thy grace is youth and gentle sport;

title: Sonnet XCVI
couplet: Both grace and faults are loved of more and less;/Thou makest faults graces that to thee resort.

title: Sonnet XCVI
couplet: As on the finger of a throned queen/The basest jewel will be well esteem'd,

title: Sonnet XCVI
couplet: So are those errors that in thee are seen/To truths translated and for true things deem'd.

title: Sonnet XCVI
couplet: How many lambs might the stem wolf betray,/If like a lamb he could his looks translate!

title: Sonnet XCVI
couplet: How many gazers mightst thou lead away,/If thou wouldst use the strength of all thy state!

title: Sonnet XCVI
couplet: But do not so; I love thee in such sort/  As, thou being mine, mine is thy good report.

title: Sonnet XCVII
couplet: How like a winter hath my absence been/From thee, the pleasure of the fleeting year!

title: Sonnet XCVII
couplet: What freezings have I felt, what dark days seen!/What old December's bareness every where!

title: Sonnet XCVII
couplet: And yet this time removed was summer's time,/The teeming autumn, big with rich increase,

title: Sonnet XCVII
couplet: Bearing the wanton burden of the prime,/Like widow'd wombs after their lords' decease:

title: Sonnet XCVII
couplet: Yet this abundant issue seem'd to me/But hope of orphans and unfather'd fruit;

title: Sonnet XCVII
couplet: For summer and his pleasures wait on thee,/And, thou away, the very birds are mute;

title: Sonnet XCVII
couplet: Or, if they sing, 'tis with so dull a cheer/  That leaves look pale, dreading the winter's near.

title: Sonnet XCVIII
couplet: From you have I been absent in the spring,/When proud-pied April dress'd in all his trim

title: Sonnet XCVIII
couplet: Hath put a spirit of youth in every thing,/That heavy Saturn laugh'd and leap'd with him.

title: Sonnet XCVIII
couplet: Yet nor the lays of birds nor the sweet smell/Of different flowers in odour and in hue

title: Sonnet XCVIII
couplet: Could make me any summer's story tell,/Or from their proud lap pluck them where they grew;

title: Sonnet XCVIII
couplet: Nor did I wonder at the lily's white,/Nor praise the deep vermilion in the rose;

title: Sonnet XCVIII
couplet: They were but sweet, but figures of delight,/Drawn after you, you pattern of all those.

title: Sonnet XCVIII
couplet: Yet seem'd it winter still, and, you away,/  As with your shadow I with these did play:

title: Sonnet XCIX
couplet: The forward violet thus did I chide:/Sweet thief, whence didst thou steal thy sweet that smells,

title: Sonnet XCIX
