couplet: If not from my love's breath? The purple pride/Which on thy soft cheek for complexion dwells

title: Sonnet XCIX
couplet: In my love's veins thou hast too grossly dyed./The lily I condemned for thy hand,

title: Sonnet XCIX
couplet: And buds of marjoram had stol'n thy hair:/The roses fearfully on thorns did stand,

title: Sonnet XCIX
couplet: One blushing shame, another white despair;/A third, nor red nor white, had stol'n of both

title: Sonnet XCIX
couplet: And to his robbery had annex'd thy breath;/But, for his theft, in pride of all his growth

title: Sonnet XCIX
couplet: A vengeful canker eat him up to death./  More flowers I noted, yet I none could see

title: Sonnet XCIX
couplet: But sweet or colour it had stol'n from thee./

title: Sonnet C
couplet: Where art thou, Muse, that thou forget'st so long/To speak of that which gives thee all thy might?

title: Sonnet C
couplet: Spend'st thou thy fury on some worthless song,/Darkening thy power to lend base subjects light?

title: Sonnet C
couplet: Return, forgetful Muse, and straight redeem/In gentle numbers time so idly spent;

title: Sonnet C
couplet: Sing to the ear that doth thy lays esteem/And gives thy pen both skill and argument.

title: Sonnet C
couplet: Rise, resty Muse, my love's sweet face survey,/If Time have any wrinkle graven there;

title: Sonnet C
couplet: If any, be a satire to decay,/And make Time's spoils despised every where.

title: Sonnet C
couplet: Give my love fame faster than Time wastes life;/  So thou prevent'st his scythe and crooked knife.

title: Sonnet CI
couplet: O truant Muse, what shall be thy amends/For thy neglect of truth in beauty dyed?

title: Sonnet CI
couplet: Both truth and beauty on my love depends;/So dost thou too, and therein dignified.

title: Sonnet CI
couplet: Make answer, Muse: wilt thou not haply say/'Truth needs no colour, with his colour fix'd;

title: Sonnet CI
couplet: Beauty no pencil, beauty's truth to lay;/But best is best, if never intermix'd?'

title: Sonnet CI
couplet: Because he needs no praise, wilt thou be dumb?/Excuse not silence so; for't lies in thee

title: Sonnet CI
couplet: To make him much outlive a gilded tomb,/And to be praised of ages yet to be.

title: Sonnet CI
couplet: Then do thy office, Muse; I teach thee how/  To make him seem long hence as he shows now.

title: Sonnet CII
couplet: My love is strengthen'd, though more weak in seeming;/I love not less, though less the show appear:

title: Sonnet CII
couplet: That love is merchandized whose rich esteeming/The owner's tongue doth publish every where.

title: Sonnet CII
couplet: Our love was new and then but in the spring/When I was wont to greet it with my lays,

title: Sonnet CII
couplet: As Philomel in summer's front doth sing/And stops her pipe in growth of riper days:

title: Sonnet CII
couplet: Not that the summer is less pleasant now/Than when her mournful hymns did hush the night,

title: Sonnet CII
couplet: But that wild music burthens every bough/And sweets grown common lose their dear delight.

title: Sonnet CII
couplet: Therefore like her I sometime hold my tongue,/  Because I would not dull you with my song.

title: Sonnet CIII
couplet: Alack, what poverty my Muse brings forth,/That having such a scope to show her pride,

title: Sonnet CIII
couplet: The argument all bare is of more worth/Than when it hath my added praise beside!

title: Sonnet CIII
couplet: O, blame me not, if I no more can write!/Look in your glass, and there appears a face

title: Sonnet CIII
couplet: That over-goes my blunt invention quite,/Dulling my lines and doing me disgrace.

title: Sonnet CIII
couplet: Were it not sinful then, striving to mend,/To mar the subject that before was well?

title: Sonnet CIII
couplet: For to no other pass my verses tend/Than of your graces and your gifts to tell;

title: Sonnet CIII
couplet: And more, much more, than in my verse can sit/  Your own glass shows you when you look in it.

title: Sonnet CIV
couplet: To me, fair friend, you never can be old,/For as you were when first your eye I eyed,

title: Sonnet CIV
couplet: Such seems your beauty still. Three winters cold/Have from the forests shook three summers' pride,

title: Sonnet CIV
couplet: Three beauteous springs to yellow autumn turn'd/In process of the seasons have I seen,

title: Sonnet CIV
couplet: Three April perfumes in three hot Junes burn'd,/Since first I saw you fresh, which yet are green.

title: Sonnet CIV
couplet: Ah! yet doth beauty, like a dial-hand,/Steal from his figure and no pace perceived;

title: Sonnet CIV
couplet: So your sweet hue, which methinks still doth stand,/Hath motion and mine eye may be deceived:

title: Sonnet CIV
couplet: For fear of which, hear this, thou age unbred;/  Ere you were born was beauty's summer dead.

title: Sonnet CV
couplet: Let not my love be call'd idolatry,/Nor my beloved as an idol show,

title: Sonnet CV
couplet: Since all alike my songs and praises be/To one, of one, still such, and ever so.

title: Sonnet CV
couplet: Kind is my love to-day, to-morrow kind,/Still constant in a wondrous excellence;

title: Sonnet CV
couplet: Therefore my verse to constancy confined,/One thing expressing, leaves out difference.

title: Sonnet CV
couplet: 'Fair, kind and true' is all my argument,/'Fair, kind, and true' varying to other words;

title: Sonnet CV
couplet: And in this change is my invention spent,/Three themes in one, which wondrous scope affords.

title: Sonnet CV
couplet: 'Fair, kind, and true,' have often lived alone,/  Which three till now never kept seat in one.

title: Sonnet CVI
couplet: When in the chronicle of wasted time/I see descriptions of the fairest wights,

title: Sonnet CVI
couplet: And beauty making beautiful old rhyme/In praise of ladies dead and lovely knights,

title: Sonnet CVI
couplet: Then, in the blazon of sweet beauty's best,/Of hand, of foot, of lip, of eye, of brow,

title: Sonnet CVI
couplet: I see their antique pen would have express'd/Even such a beauty as you master now.

title: Sonnet CVI
couplet: So all their praises are but prophecies/Of this our time, all you prefiguring;

title: Sonnet CVI
couplet: And, for they look'd but with divining eyes,/They had not skill enough your worth to sing:

title: Sonnet CVI
couplet: For we, which now behold these present days,/  Had eyes to wonder, but lack tongues to praise.

title: Sonnet CVII
couplet: Not mine own fears, nor the prophetic soul/Of the wide world dreaming on things to come,

title: Sonnet CVII
couplet: Can yet the lease of my true love control,/Supposed as forfeit to a confined doom.

title: Sonnet CVII
couplet: The mortal moon hath her eclipse endured/And the sad augurs mock their own presage;

title: Sonnet CVII
couplet: Incertainties now crown themselves assured/And peace proclaims olives of endless age.

title: Sonnet CVII
couplet: Now with the drops of this most balmy time/My love looks fresh, and death to me subscribes,

title: Sonnet CVII
couplet: Since, spite of him, I'll live in this poor rhyme,/While he insults o'er dull and speechless tribes:

title: Sonnet CVII
couplet: And thou in this shalt find thy monument,/  When tyrants' crests and tombs of brass are spent.

title: Sonnet CVIII
couplet: What's in the brain that ink may character/Which hath not figured to thee my true spirit?

title: Sonnet CVIII
couplet: What's new to speak, what new to register,/That may express my love or thy dear merit?

title: Sonnet CVIII
couplet: Nothing, sweet boy; but yet, like prayers divine,/I must, each day say o'er the very same,

title: Sonnet CVIII
couplet: Counting no old thing old, thou mine, I thine,/Even as when first I hallow'd thy fair name.

title: Sonnet CVIII
couplet: So that eternal love in love's fresh case/Weighs not the dust and injury of age,

title: Sonnet CVIII
couplet: Nor gives to necessary wrinkles place,/But makes antiquity for aye his page,

title: Sonnet CVIII
couplet: Finding the first conceit of love there bred/  Where time and outward form would show it dead.

title: Sonnet CIX
couplet: O, never say that I was false of heart,/Though absence seem'd my flame to qualify.

title: Sonnet CIX
couplet: As easy might I from myself depart/As from my soul, which in thy breast doth lie:

title: Sonnet CIX
couplet: That is my home of love: if I have ranged,/Like him that travels I return again,

title: Sonnet CIX
couplet: Just to the time, not with the time exchanged,/So that myself bring water for my stain.

title: Sonnet CIX
couplet: Never believe, though in my nature reign'd/All frailties that besiege all kinds of blood,

title: Sonnet CIX
couplet: That it could so preposterously be stain'd,/To leave for nothing all thy sum of good;

title: Sonnet CIX
couplet: For nothing this wide universe I call,/  Save thou, my rose; in it thou art my all.

title: Sonnet CX
couplet: Alas, 'tis true I have gone here and there/And made myself a motley to the view,

title: Sonnet CX
couplet: Gored mine own thoughts, sold cheap what is most dear,/Made old offences of affections new;

title: Sonnet CX
couplet: Most true it is that I have look'd on truth/Askance and strangely: but, by all above,

title: Sonnet CX
couplet: These blenches gave my heart another youth,/And worse essays proved thee my best of love.

title: Sonnet CX
couplet: Now all is done, have what shall have no end:/Mine appetite I never more will grind

title: Sonnet CX
couplet: On newer proof, to try an older friend,/A god in love, to whom I am confined.

title: Sonnet CX
couplet: Then give me welcome, next my heaven the best,/  Even to thy pure and most most loving breast.

title: Sonnet CXI
couplet: O, for my sake do you with Fortune chide,/The guilty goddess of my harmful deeds,

title: Sonnet CXI
couplet: That did not better for my life provide/Than public means which public manners breeds.

title: Sonnet CXI
couplet: Thence comes it that my name receives a brand,/And almost thence my nature is subdued

title: Sonnet CXI
couplet: To what it works in, like the dyer's hand:/Pity me then and wish I were renew'd;

title: Sonnet CXI
couplet: Whilst, like a willing patient, I will drink/Potions of eisel 'gainst my strong infection

title: Sonnet CXI
couplet: No bitterness that I will bitter think,/Nor double penance, to correct correction.

title: Sonnet CXI
couplet: Pity me then, dear friend, and I assure ye/  Even that your pity is enough to cure me.

title: Sonnet CXII
couplet: Your love and pity doth the impression fill/Which vulgar scandal stamp'd upon my brow;

title: Sonnet CXII
couplet: For what care I who calls me well or ill,/So you o'er-green my bad, my good allow?

title: Sonnet CXII
couplet: You are my all the world, and I must strive/To know my shames and praises from your tongue:

title: Sonnet CXII
couplet: None else to me, nor I to none alive,/That my steel'd sense or changes right or wrong.

title: Sonnet CXII
couplet: In so profound abysm I throw all care/Of others' voices, that my adder's sense

title: Sonnet CXII
couplet: To critic and to flatterer stopped are./Mark how with my neglect I do dispense:

title: Sonnet CXII
couplet: You are so strongly in my purpose bred/  That all the world besides methinks are dead.

title: Sonnet CXIII
couplet: Since I left you, mine eye is in my mind;/And that which governs me to go about

title: Sonnet CXIII
couplet: Doth part his function and is partly blind,/Seems seeing, but effectually is out;

title: Sonnet CXIII
couplet: For it no form delivers to the heart/Of bird of flower, or shape, which it doth latch:

title: Sonnet CXIII
couplet: Of his quick objects hath the mind no part,/Nor his own vision holds what it doth catch:

title: Sonnet CXIII
couplet: For if it see the rudest or gentlest sight,/The most sweet favour or deformed'st creature,

title: Sonnet CXIII
couplet: The mountain or the sea, the day or night,/The crow or dove, it shapes them to your feature:

title: Sonnet CXIII
couplet: Incapable of more, replete with you,/  My most true mind thus makes mine eye untrue.

title: Sonnet CXIV
couplet: Or whether doth my mind, being crown'd with you,/Drink up the monarch's plague, this flattery?

title: Sonnet CXIV
couplet: Or whether shall I say, mine eye saith true,/And that your love taught it this alchemy,

title: Sonnet CXIV
couplet: To make of monsters and things indigest/Such cherubins as your sweet self resemble,

title: Sonnet CXIV
couplet: Creating every bad a perfect best,/As fast as objects to his beams assemble?

title: Sonnet CXIV
couplet: O,'tis the first; 'tis flattery in my seeing,/And my great mind most kingly drinks it up:

title: Sonnet CXIV
couplet: Mine eye well knows what with his gust is 'greeing,/And to his palate doth prepare the cup:

title: Sonnet CXIV
couplet: If it be poison'd, 'tis the lesser sin/  That mine eye loves it and doth first begin.

title: Sonnet CXV
couplet: Those lines that I before have writ do lie,/Even those that said I could not love you dearer:

title: Sonnet CXV
couplet: Yet then my judgment knew no reason why/My most full flame should afterwards burn clearer.

title: Sonnet CXV
couplet: But reckoning time, whose million'd accidents/Creep in 'twixt vows and change decrees of kings,

title: Sonnet CXV
couplet: Tan sacred beauty, blunt the sharp'st intents,/Divert strong minds to the course of altering things;

title: Sonnet CXV
couplet: Alas, why, fearing of time's tyranny,/Might I not then say 'Now I love you best,'

title: Sonnet CXV
couplet: When I was certain o'er incertainty,/Crowning the present, doubting of the rest?

title: Sonnet CXV
couplet: Love is a babe; then might I not say so,/  To give full growth to that which still doth grow?

title: Sonnet CXVI
couplet: Let me not to the marriage of true minds/Admit impediments. Love is not love

title: Sonnet CXVI
couplet: Which alters when it alteration finds,/Or bends with the remover to remove:

title: Sonnet CXVI
couplet: O no! it is an ever-fixed mark/That looks on tempests and is never shaken;

title: Sonnet CXVI
couplet: It is the star to every wandering bark,/Whose worth's unknown, although his height be taken.

title: Sonnet CXVI
couplet: Love's not Time's fool, though rosy lips and cheeks/Within his bending sickle's compass come:

title: Sonnet CXVI
couplet: Love alters not with his brief hours and weeks,/But bears it out even to the edge of doom.

title: Sonnet CXVI
couplet: If this be error and upon me proved,/  I never writ, nor no man ever loved.

title: Sonnet CXVII
couplet: Accuse me thus: that I have scanted all/Wherein I should your great deserts repay,

title: Sonnet CXVII
couplet: Forgot upon your dearest love to call,/Whereto all bonds do tie me day by day;

title: Sonnet CXVII
couplet: That I have frequent been with unknown minds/And given to time your own dear-purchased right

title: Sonnet CXVII
couplet: That I have hoisted sail to all the winds/Which should transport me farthest from your sight.

title: Sonnet CXVII
couplet: Book both my wilfulness and errors down/And on just proof surmise accumulate;

title: Sonnet CXVII
couplet: Bring me within the level of your frown,/But shoot not at me in your waken'd hate;

title: Sonnet CXVII
couplet: Since my appeal says I did strive to prove/  The constancy and virtue of your love.

title: Sonnet CXVIII
couplet: Like as, to make our appetites more keen,/With eager compounds we our palate urge,

title: Sonnet CXVIII
couplet: As, to prevent our maladies unseen,/We sicken to shun sickness when we purge,

title: Sonnet CXVIII
couplet: Even so, being tuff of your ne'er-cloying sweetness,/To bitter sauces did I frame my feeding

title: Sonnet CXVIII
couplet: And, sick of welfare, found a kind of meetness/To be diseased ere that there was true needing.

title: Sonnet CXVIII
couplet: Thus policy in love, to anticipate/The ills that were not, grew to faults assured

title: Sonnet CXVIII
couplet: And brought to medicine a healthful state/Which, rank of goodness, would by ill be cured:

title: Sonnet CXVIII
couplet: But thence I learn, and find the lesson true,/  Drugs poison him that so fell sick of you.

title: Sonnet CXIX
couplet: What potions have I drunk of Siren tears,/Distill'd from limbecks foul as hell within,

title: Sonnet CXIX
couplet: Applying fears to hopes and hopes to fears,/Still losing when I saw myself to win!

title: Sonnet CXIX
couplet: What wretched errors hath my heart committed,/Whilst it hath thought itself so blessed never!

title: Sonnet CXIX
couplet: How have mine eyes out of their spheres been fitted/In the distraction of this madding fever!

title: Sonnet CXIX
couplet: O benefit of ill! now I find true/That better is by evil still made better;

title: Sonnet CXIX
couplet: And ruin'd love, when it is built anew,/Grows fairer than at first, more strong, far greater.

title: Sonnet CXIX
couplet: So I return rebuked to my content/  And gain by ill thrice more than I have spent.

title: Sonnet CXX
couplet: That you were once unkind befriends me now,/And for that sorrow which I then did feel

title: Sonnet CXX
couplet: Needs must I under my transgression bow,/Unless my nerves were brass or hammer'd steel.

title: Sonnet CXX
couplet: For if you were by my unkindness shaken/As I by yours, you've pass'd a hell of time,

title: Sonnet CXX
couplet: And I, a tyrant, have no leisure taken/To weigh how once I suffered in your crime.

title: Sonnet CXX
couplet: O, that our night of woe might have remember'd/My deepest sense, how hard true sorrow hits,

title: Sonnet CXX
couplet: And soon to you, as you to me, then tender'd/The humble slave which wounded bosoms fits!

title: Sonnet CXX
couplet: But that your trespass now becomes a fee;/  Mine ransoms yours, and yours must ransom me.

title: Sonnet CXXI
couplet: 'Tis better to be vile than vile esteem'd,/When not to be receives reproach of being,

title: Sonnet CXXI
couplet: And the just pleasure lost which is so deem'd/Not by our feeling but by others' seeing:

title: Sonnet CXXI
couplet: For why should others false adulterate eyes/Give salutation to my sportive blood?

title: Sonnet CXXI
couplet: Or on my frailties why are frailer spies,/Which in their wills count bad what I think good?

title: Sonnet CXXI
couplet: No, I am that I am, and they that level/At my abuses reckon up their own:

title: Sonnet CXXI
couplet: I may be straight, though they themselves be bevel;/By their rank thoughts my deeds must not be shown;

title: Sonnet CXXI
couplet: Unless this general evil they maintain,/  All men are bad, and in their badness reign.

title: Sonnet CXXII
couplet: Thy gift, thy tables, are within my brain/Full character'd with lasting memory,

title: Sonnet CXXII
couplet: Which shall above that idle rank remain/Beyond all date, even to eternity;

title: Sonnet CXXII
couplet: Or at the least, so long as brain and heart/Have faculty by nature to subsist;

title: Sonnet CXXII
couplet: Till each to razed oblivion yield his part/Of thee, thy record never can be miss'd.

title: Sonnet CXXII
couplet: That poor retention could not so much hold,/Nor need I tallies thy dear love to score;

title: Sonnet CXXII
couplet: Therefore to give them from me was I bold,/To trust those tables that receive thee more:

title: Sonnet CXXII
couplet: To keep an adjunct to remember thee/  Were to import forgetfulness in me.

title: Sonnet CXXIII
couplet: No, Time, thou shalt not boast that I do change:/Thy pyramids built up with newer might

title: Sonnet CXXIII
couplet: To me are nothing novel, nothing strange;/They are but dressings of a former sight.

title: Sonnet CXXIII
couplet: Our dates are brief, and therefore we admire/What thou dost foist upon us that is old,

title: Sonnet CXXIII
couplet: And rather make them born to our desire/Than think that we before have heard them told.

title: Sonnet CXXIII
couplet: Thy registers and thee I both defy,/Not wondering at the present nor the past,

title: Sonnet CXXIII
couplet: For thy records and what we see doth lie,/Made more or less by thy continual haste.

title: Sonnet CXXIII
couplet: This I do vow and this shall ever be;/  I will be true, despite thy scythe and thee.

title: Sonnet CXXIV
couplet: If my dear love were but the child of state,/It might for Fortune's bastard be unfather'd'

title: Sonnet CXXIV
couplet: As subject to Time's love or to Time's hate,/Weeds among weeds, or flowers with flowers gather'd.

title: Sonnet CXXIV
couplet: No, it was builded far from accident;/It suffers not in smiling pomp, nor falls

title: Sonnet CXXIV
couplet: Under the blow of thralled discontent,/Whereto the inviting time our fashion calls:

title: Sonnet CXXIV
couplet: It fears not policy, that heretic,/Which works on leases of short-number'd hours,

title: Sonnet CXXIV
couplet: But all alone stands hugely politic,/That it nor grows with heat nor drowns with showers.

title: Sonnet CXXIV
couplet: To this I witness call the fools of time,/  Which die for goodness, who have lived for crime.

title: Sonnet CXXV
couplet: Were 't aught to me I bore the canopy,/With my extern the outward honouring,

title: Sonnet CXXV
couplet: Or laid great bases for eternity,/Which prove more short than waste or ruining?

title: Sonnet CXXV
couplet: Have I not seen dwellers on form and favour/Lose all, and more, by paying too much rent,

title: Sonnet CXXV
couplet: For compound sweet forgoing simple savour,/Pitiful thrivers, in their gazing spent?

title: Sonnet CXXV
couplet: No, let me be obsequious in thy heart,/And take thou my oblation, poor but free,

title: Sonnet CXXV
couplet: Which is not mix'd with seconds, knows no art,/But mutual render, only me for thee.

title: Sonnet CXXV
couplet: Hence, thou suborn'd informer! a true soul/  When most impeach'd stands least in thy control.

title: Sonnet CXXVI
couplet: O thou, my lovely boy, who in thy power/Dost hold Time's fickle glass, his sickle, hour;

title: Sonnet CXXVI
couplet: Who hast by waning grown, and therein show'st/Thy lovers withering as thy sweet self grow'st;

title: Sonnet CXXVI
couplet: If Nature, sovereign mistress over wrack,/As thou goest onwards, still will pluck thee back,

title: Sonnet CXXVI
couplet: She keeps thee to this purpose, that her skill/May time disgrace and wretched minutes kill.

title: Sonnet CXXVI
couplet: Yet fear her, O thou minion of her pleasure!/She may detain, but not still keep, her treasure:

title: Sonnet CXXVI
couplet: Her audit, though delay'd, answer'd must be,/  And her quietus is to render thee.

title: Sonnet CXXVII
couplet: In the old age black was not counted fair,/Or if it were, it bore not beauty's name;

title: Sonnet CXXVII
couplet: But now is black beauty's successive heir,/And beauty slander'd with a bastard shame:

title: Sonnet CXXVII
couplet: For since each hand hath put on nature's power,/Fairing the foul with art's false borrow'd face,

title: Sonnet CXXVII
couplet: Sweet beauty hath no name, no holy bower,/But is profaned, if not lives in disgrace.

title: Sonnet CXXVII
couplet: Therefore my mistress' brows are raven black,/Her eyes so suited, and they mourners seem

title: Sonnet CXXVII
couplet: At such who, not born fair, no beauty lack,/Slandering creation with a false esteem:

title: Sonnet CXXVII
couplet: Yet so they mourn, becoming of their woe,/  That every tongue says beauty should look so.

title: Sonnet CXXVIII
couplet: How oft, when thou, my music, music play'st,/Upon that blessed wood whose motion sounds

title: Sonnet CXXVIII
couplet: With thy sweet fingers, when thou gently sway'st/The wiry concord that mine ear confounds,

title: Sonnet CXXVIII
couplet: Do I envy those jacks that nimble leap/To kiss the tender inward of thy hand,

title: Sonnet CXXVIII
couplet: Whilst my poor lips, which should that harvest reap,/At the wood's boldness by thee blushing stand!

title: Sonnet CXXVIII
couplet: To be so tickled, they would change their state/And situation with those dancing chips,

title: Sonnet CXXVIII
couplet: O'er whom thy fingers walk with gentle gait,/Making dead wood more blest than living lips.

title: Sonnet CXXVIII
couplet: Since saucy jacks so happy are in this,/  Give them thy fingers, me thy lips to kiss.

title: Sonnet CXXIX
couplet: The expense of spirit in a waste of shame/Is lust in action; and till action, lust

title: Sonnet CXXIX
couplet: Is perjured, murderous, bloody, full of blame,/Savage, extreme, rude, cruel, not to trust,

title: Sonnet CXXIX
couplet: Enjoy'd no sooner but despised straight,/Past reason hunted, and no sooner had

title: Sonnet CXXIX
couplet: Past reason hated, as a swallow'd bait/On purpose laid to make the taker mad;

title: Sonnet CXXIX
couplet: Mad in pursuit and in possession so;/Had, having, and in quest to have, extreme;

title: Sonnet CXXIX
couplet: A bliss in proof, and proved, a very woe;/Before, a joy proposed; behind, a dream.

title: Sonnet CXXIX
couplet: All this the world well knows; yet none knows well/  To shun the heaven that leads men to this hell.

title: Sonnet CXXX
couplet: My mistress' eyes are nothing like the sun;/Coral is far more red than her lips' red;

title: Sonnet CXXX
couplet: If snow be white, why then her breasts are dun;/If hairs be wires, black wires grow on her head.

title: Sonnet CXXX
couplet: I have seen roses damask'd, red and white,/But no such roses see I in her cheeks;

title: Sonnet CXXX
couplet: And in some perfumes is there more delight/Than in the breath that from my mistress reeks.

title: Sonnet CXXX
couplet: I love to hear her speak, yet well I know/That music hath a far more pleasing sound;

title: Sonnet CXXX
couplet: I grant I never saw a goddess go;/My mistress, when she walks, treads on the ground:

title: Sonnet CXXX
couplet: And yet, by heaven, I think my love as rare/  As any she belied with false compare.

title: Sonnet CXXXI
couplet: Thou art as tyrannous, so as thou art,/As those whose beauties proudly make them cruel;

title: Sonnet CXXXI
couplet: For well thou know'st to my dear doting heart/Thou art the fairest and most precious jewel.

title: Sonnet CXXXI
couplet: Yet, in good faith, some say that thee behold/Thy face hath not the power to make love groan:

title: Sonnet CXXXI
couplet: To say they err I dare not be so bold,/Although I swear it to myself alone.

title: Sonnet CXXXI
couplet: And, to be sure that is not false I swear,/A thousand groans, but thinking on thy face,

title: Sonnet CXXXI
couplet: One on another's neck, do witness bear/Thy black is fairest in my judgment's place.

title: Sonnet CXXXI
couplet: In nothing art thou black save in thy deeds,/  And thence this slander, as I think, proceeds.

title: Sonnet CXXXII
couplet: Thine eyes I love, and they, as pitying me,/Knowing thy heart torments me with disdain,

title: Sonnet CXXXII
couplet: Have put on black and loving mourners be,/Looking with pretty ruth upon my pain.

title: Sonnet CXXXII
couplet: And truly not the morning sun of heaven/Better becomes the grey cheeks of the east,

title: Sonnet CXXXII
couplet: Nor that full star that ushers in the even/Doth half that glory to the sober west,

title: Sonnet CXXXII
couplet: As those two mourning eyes become thy face:/O, let it then as well beseem thy heart

title: Sonnet CXXXII
couplet: To mourn for me, since mourning doth thee grace,/And suit thy pity like in every part.

title: Sonnet CXXXII
couplet: Then will I swear beauty herself is black/  And all they foul that thy complexion lack.

title: Sonnet CXXXIII
couplet: Beshrew that heart that makes my heart to groan/For that deep wound it gives my friend and me!

title: Sonnet CXXXIII
couplet: Is't not enough to torture me alone,/But slave to slavery my sweet'st friend must be?

title: Sonnet CXXXIII
couplet: Me from myself thy cruel eye hath taken,/And my next self thou harder hast engross'd:

title: Sonnet CXXXIII
couplet: Of him, myself, and thee, I am forsaken;/A torment thrice threefold thus to be cross'd.

title: Sonnet CXXXIII
couplet: Prison my heart in thy steel bosom's ward,/But then my friend's heart let my poor heart bail;

title: Sonnet CXXXIII
couplet: Whoe'er keeps me, let my heart be his guard;/Thou canst not then use rigor in my gaol:

title: Sonnet CXXXIII
couplet: And yet thou wilt; for I, being pent in thee,/  Perforce am thine, and all that is in me.

title: Sonnet CXXXIV
couplet: So, now I have confess'd that he is thine,/And I myself am mortgaged to thy will,

title: Sonnet CXXXIV
couplet: Myself I'll forfeit, so that other mine/Thou wilt restore, to be my comfort still:

title: Sonnet CXXXIV
couplet: But thou wilt not, nor he will not be free,/For thou art covetous and he is kind;

title: Sonnet CXXXIV
couplet: He learn'd but surety-like to write for me/Under that bond that him as fast doth bind.

title: Sonnet CXXXIV
couplet: The statute of thy beauty thou wilt take,/Thou usurer, that put'st forth all to use,

title: Sonnet CXXXIV
couplet: And sue a friend came debtor for my sake;/So him I lose through my unkind abuse.

title: Sonnet CXXXIV
couplet: Him have I lost; thou hast both him and me:/  He pays the whole, and yet am I not free.

title: Sonnet CXXXV
couplet: Whoever hath her wish, thou hast thy 'Will,'/And 'Will' to boot, and 'Will' in overplus;

title: Sonnet CXXXV
couplet: More than enough am I that vex thee still,/To thy sweet will making addition thus.

title: Sonnet CXXXV
couplet: Wilt thou, whose will is large and spacious,/Not once vouchsafe to hide my will in thine?

title: Sonnet CXXXV
couplet: Shall will in others seem right gracious,/And in my will no fair acceptance shine?

title: Sonnet CXXXV
couplet: The sea all water, yet receives rain still/And in abundance addeth to his store;

title: Sonnet CXXXV
couplet: So thou, being rich in 'Will,' add to thy 'Will'/One will of mine, to make thy large 'Will' more.

title: Sonnet CXXXV
couplet: Let no unkind, no fair beseechers kill;/  Think all but one, and me in that one 'Will.'

title: Sonnet CXXXVI
couplet: If thy soul cheque thee that I come so near,/Swear to thy blind soul that I was thy 'Will,'

title: Sonnet CXXXVI
couplet: And will, thy soul knows, is admitted there;/Thus far for love my love-suit, sweet, fulfil.

title: Sonnet CXXXVI
couplet: 'Will' will fulfil the treasure of thy love,/Ay, fill it full with wills, and my will one.

title: Sonnet CXXXVI
couplet: In things of great receipt with ease we prove/Among a number one is reckon'd none:

title: Sonnet CXXXVI
couplet: Then in the number let me pass untold,/Though in thy stores' account I one must be;

title: Sonnet CXXXVI
couplet: For nothing hold me, so it please thee hold/That nothing me, a something sweet to thee:

title: Sonnet CXXXVI
couplet: Make but my name thy love, and love that still,/  And then thou lovest me, for my name is 'Will.'

title: Sonnet CXXXVII
couplet: Thou blind fool, Love, what dost thou to mine eyes,/That they behold, and see not what they see?

title: Sonnet CXXXVII
couplet: They know what beauty is, see where it lies,/Yet what the best is take the worst to be.

title: Sonnet CXXXVII
couplet: If eyes corrupt by over-partial looks/Be anchor'd in the bay where all men ride,

title: Sonnet CXXXVII
couplet: Why of eyes' falsehood hast thou forged hooks,/Whereto the judgment of my heart is tied?

title: Sonnet CXXXVII
couplet: Why should my heart think that a several plot/Which my heart knows the wide world's common place?

title: Sonnet CXXXVII
couplet: Or mine eyes seeing this, say this is not,/To put fair truth upon so foul a face?

title: Sonnet CXXXVII
couplet: In things right true my heart and eyes have erred,/  And to this false plague are they now transferr'd.

title: Sonnet CXXXVIII
couplet: When my love swears that she is made of truth/I do believe her, though I know she lies,

title: Sonnet CXXXVIII
couplet: That she might think me some untutor'd youth,/Unlearned in the world's false subtleties.

title: Sonnet CXXXVIII
couplet: Thus vainly thinking that she thinks me young,/Although she knows my days are past the best,

title: Sonnet CXXXVIII
couplet: Simply I credit her false speaking tongue:/On both sides thus is simple truth suppress'd.

title: Sonnet CXXXVIII
couplet: But wherefore says she not she is unjust?/And wherefore say not I that I am old?

title: Sonnet CXXXVIII
couplet: O, love's best habit is in seeming trust,/And age in love loves not to have years told:

title: Sonnet CXXXVIII
couplet: Therefore I lie with her and she with me,/  And in our faults by lies we flatter'd be.

title: Sonnet CXXXIX
couplet: O, call not me to justify the wrong/That thy unkindness lays upon my heart;

title: Sonnet CXXXIX
couplet: Wound me not with thine eye but with thy tongue;/Use power with power and slay me not by art.

title: Sonnet CXXXIX
couplet: Tell me thou lovest elsewhere, but in my sight,/Dear heart, forbear to glance thine eye aside:

title: Sonnet CXXXIX
couplet: What need'st thou wound with cunning when thy might/Is more than my o'er-press'd defense can bide?

title: Sonnet CXXXIX
couplet: Let me excuse thee: ah! my love well knows/Her pretty looks have been mine enemies,

title: Sonnet CXXXIX
couplet: And therefore from my face she turns my foes,/That they elsewhere might dart their injuries:

title: Sonnet CXXXIX
couplet: Yet do not so; but since I am near slain,/  Kill me outright with looks and rid my pain.

title: Sonnet CXL
couplet: Be wise as thou art cruel; do not press/My tongue-tied patience with too much disdain;

title: Sonnet CXL
couplet: Lest sorrow lend me words and words express/The manner of my pity-wanting pain.

title: Sonnet CXL
couplet: If I might teach thee wit, better it were,/Though not to love, yet, love, to tell me so;

title: Sonnet CXL
couplet: As testy sick men, when their deaths be near,/No news but health from their physicians know;

title: Sonnet CXL
couplet: For if I should despair, I should grow mad,/And in my madness might speak ill of thee:

title: Sonnet CXL
couplet: Now this ill-wresting world is grown so bad,/Mad slanderers by mad ears believed be,

title: Sonnet CXL
couplet: That I may not be so, nor thou belied,/  Bear thine eyes straight, though thy proud heart go wide.

title: Sonnet CXLI
couplet: In faith, I do not love thee with mine eyes,/For they in thee a thousand errors note;

title: Sonnet CXLI
couplet: But 'tis my heart that loves what they despise,/Who in despite of view is pleased to dote;

title: Sonnet CXLI
couplet: Nor are mine ears with thy tongue's tune delighted,/Nor tender feeling, to base touches prone,

title: Sonnet CXLI
couplet: Nor taste, nor smell, desire to be invited/To any sensual feast with thee alone:

title: Sonnet CXLI
couplet: But my five wits nor my five senses can/Dissuade one foolish heart from serving thee,

title: Sonnet CXLI
couplet: Who leaves unsway'd the likeness of a man,/Thy proud hearts slave and vassal wretch to be:

title: Sonnet CXLI
couplet: Only my plague thus far I count my gain,/  That she that makes me sin awards me pain.

title: Sonnet CXLII
couplet: Love is my sin and thy dear virtue hate,/Hate of my sin, grounded on sinful loving:

title: Sonnet CXLII
couplet: O, but with mine compare thou thine own state,/And thou shalt find it merits not reproving;

title: Sonnet CXLII
couplet: Or, if it do, not from those lips of thine,/That have profaned their scarlet ornaments

title: Sonnet CXLII
couplet: And seal'd false bonds of love as oft as mine,/Robb'd others' beds' revenues of their rents.

title: Sonnet CXLII
couplet: Be it lawful I love thee, as thou lovest those/Whom thine eyes woo as mine importune thee:

title: Sonnet CXLII
couplet: Root pity in thy heart, that when it grows/Thy pity may deserve to pitied be.

title: Sonnet CXLII
couplet: If thou dost seek to have what thou dost hide,/  By self-example mayst thou be denied!

title: Sonnet CXLIII
couplet: Lo! as a careful housewife runs to catch/One of her feather'd creatures broke away,

title: Sonnet CXLIII
couplet: Sets down her babe and makes an swift dispatch/In pursuit of the thing she would have stay,

title: Sonnet CXLIII
couplet: Whilst her neglected child holds her in chase,/Cries to catch her whose busy care is bent

title: Sonnet CXLIII
couplet: To follow that which flies before her face,/Not prizing her poor infant's discontent;

title: Sonnet CXLIII
couplet: So runn'st thou after that which flies from thee,/Whilst I thy babe chase thee afar behind;

title: Sonnet CXLIII
couplet: But if thou catch thy hope, turn back to me,/And play the mother's part, kiss me, be kind:

title: Sonnet CXLIII
couplet: So will I pray that thou mayst have thy 'Will,'/  If thou turn back, and my loud crying still.

title: Sonnet CXLIV
couplet: Two loves I have of comfort and despair,/Which like two spirits do suggest me still:

title: Sonnet CXLIV
couplet: The better angel is a man right fair,/The worser spirit a woman colour'd ill.

title: Sonnet CXLIV
couplet: To win me soon to hell, my female evil/Tempteth my better angel from my side,

title: Sonnet CXLIV
couplet: And would corrupt my saint to be a devil,/Wooing his purity with her foul pride.

title: Sonnet CXLIV
couplet: And whether that my angel be turn'd fiend/Suspect I may, but not directly tell;

title: Sonnet CXLIV
couplet: But being both from me, both to each friend,/I guess one angel in another's hell:

title: Sonnet CXLIV
couplet: Yet this shall I ne'er know, but live in doubt,/  Till my bad angel fire my good one out.

title: Sonnet CXLV
couplet: Those lips that Love's own hand did make/Breathed forth the sound that said 'I hate'

title: Sonnet CXLV
couplet: To me that languish'd for her sake;/But when she saw my woeful state,

title: Sonnet CXLV
couplet: Straight in her heart did mercy come,/Chiding that tongue that ever sweet

title: Sonnet CXLV
couplet: Was used in giving gentle doom,/And taught it thus anew to greet:

title: Sonnet CXLV
couplet: 'I hate' she alter'd with an end,/That follow'd it as gentle day

title: Sonnet CXLV
couplet: Doth follow night, who like a fiend/From heaven to hell is flown away;

title: Sonnet CXLV
couplet: 'I hate' from hate away she threw,/  And saved my life, saying 'not you.'

title: Sonnet CXLVI
couplet: Poor soul, the centre of my sinful earth,/[         ] these rebel powers that thee array;

title: Sonnet CXLVI
couplet: Why dost thou pine within and suffer dearth,/Painting thy outward walls so costly gay?

title: Sonnet CXLVI
couplet: Why so large cost, having so short a lease,/Dost thou upon thy fading mansion spend?

title: Sonnet CXLVI
couplet: Shall worms, inheritors of this excess,/Eat up thy charge? is this thy body's end?

title: Sonnet CXLVI
couplet: Then soul, live thou upon thy servant's loss,/And let that pine to aggravate thy store;

title: Sonnet CXLVI
couplet: Buy terms divine in selling hours of dross;/Within be fed, without be rich no more:

title: Sonnet CXLVI
couplet: So shalt thou feed on Death, that feeds on men,/  And Death once dead, there's no more dying then.

title: Sonnet CXLVII
couplet: My love is as a fever, longing still/For that which longer nurseth the disease,

title: Sonnet CXLVII
couplet: Feeding on that which doth preserve the ill,/The uncertain sickly appetite to please.

title: Sonnet CXLVII
couplet: My reason, the physician to my love,/Angry that his prescriptions are not kept,

title: Sonnet CXLVII
couplet: Hath left me, and I desperate now approve/Desire is death, which physic did except.

title: Sonnet CXLVII
couplet: Past cure I am, now reason is past care,/And frantic-mad with evermore unrest;

title: Sonnet CXLVII
couplet: My thoughts and my discourse as madmen's are,/At random from the truth vainly express'd;

title: Sonnet CXLVII
couplet: For I have sworn thee fair and thought thee bright,/  Who art as black as hell, as dark as night.

title: Sonnet CXLVIII
couplet: O me, what eyes hath Love put in my head,/Which have no correspondence with true sight!

title: Sonnet CXLVIII
couplet: Or, if they have, where is my judgment fled,/That censures falsely what they see aright?

title: Sonnet CXLVIII
couplet: If that be fair whereon my false eyes dote,/What means the world to say it is not so?

title: Sonnet CXLVIII
couplet: If it be not, then love doth well denote/Love's eye is not so true as all men's 'No.'

title: Sonnet CXLVIII
couplet: How can it? O, how can Love's eye be true,/That is so vex'd with watching and with tears?

title: Sonnet CXLVIII
couplet: No marvel then, though I mistake my view;/The sun itself sees not till heaven clears.

title: Sonnet CXLVIII
couplet: O cunning Love! with tears thou keep'st me blind,/  Lest eyes well-seeing thy foul faults should find.

title: Sonnet CXLIX
couplet: Canst thou, O cruel! say I love thee not,/When I against myself with thee partake?

title: Sonnet CXLIX
couplet: Do I not think on thee, when I forgot/Am of myself, all tyrant, for thy sake?

title: Sonnet CXLIX
couplet: Who hateth thee that I do call my friend?/On whom frown'st thou that I do fawn upon?

title: Sonnet CXLIX
couplet: Nay, if thou lour'st on me, do I not spend/Revenge upon myself with present moan?

title: Sonnet CXLIX
couplet: What merit do I in myself respect,/That is so proud thy service to despise,

title: Sonnet CXLIX
couplet: When all my best doth worship thy defect,/Commanded by the motion of thine eyes?

title: Sonnet CXLIX
couplet: But, love, hate on, for now I know thy mind;/  Those that can see thou lovest, and I am blind.

title: Sonnet CL
couplet: O, from what power hast thou this powerful might/With insufficiency my heart to sway?

title: Sonnet CL
couplet: To make me give the lie to my true sight,/And swear that brightness doth not grace the day?

title: Sonnet CL
couplet: Whence hast thou this becoming of things ill,/That in the very refuse of thy deeds

title: Sonnet CL
couplet: There is such strength and warrantize of skill/That, in my mind, thy worst all best exceeds?

title: Sonnet CL
couplet: Who taught thee how to make me love thee more/The more I hear and see just cause of hate?

title: Sonnet CL
couplet: O, though I love what others do abhor,/With others thou shouldst not abhor my state:

title: Sonnet CL
couplet: If thy unworthiness raised love in me,/  More worthy I to be beloved of thee.

title: Sonnet CLI
couplet: Love is too young to know what conscience is;/Yet who knows not conscience is born of love?

title: Sonnet CLI
couplet: Then, gentle cheater, urge not my amiss,/Lest guilty of my faults thy sweet self prove:

title: Sonnet CLI
couplet: For, thou betraying me, I do betray/My nobler part to my gross body's treason;

title: Sonnet CLI
couplet: My soul doth tell my body that he may/Triumph in love; flesh stays no father reason;

title: Sonnet CLI
couplet: But, rising at thy name, doth point out thee/As his triumphant prize. Proud of this pride,

title: Sonnet CLI
couplet: He is contented thy poor drudge to be,/To stand in thy affairs, fall by thy side.

title: Sonnet CLI
couplet: No want of conscience hold it that I call/  Her 'love' for whose dear love I rise and fall.

title: Sonnet CLII
couplet: In loving thee thou know'st I am forsworn,/But thou art twice forsworn, to me love swearing,

title: Sonnet CLII
couplet: In act thy bed-vow broke and new faith torn,/In vowing new hate after new love bearing.

title: Sonnet CLII
couplet: But why of two oaths' breach do I accuse thee,/When I break twenty? I am perjured most;

title: Sonnet CLII
couplet: For all my vows are oaths but to misuse thee/And all my honest faith in thee is lost,

title: Sonnet CLII
couplet: For I have sworn deep oaths of thy deep kindness,/Oaths of thy love, thy truth, thy constancy,

title: Sonnet CLII
couplet: And, to enlighten thee, gave eyes to blindness,/Or made them swear against the thing they see;

title: Sonnet CLII
couplet: For I have sworn thee fair; more perjured I,/  To swear against the truth so foul a lie!

title: Sonnet CLIII
couplet: Cupid laid by his brand, and fell asleep:/A maid of Dian's this advantage found,

title: Sonnet CLIII
couplet: And his love-kindling fire did quickly steep/In a cold valley-fountain of that ground;

title: Sonnet CLIII
couplet: Which borrow'd from this holy fire of Love/A dateless lively heat, still to endure,

title: Sonnet CLIII
couplet: And grew a seething bath, which yet men prove/Against strange maladies a sovereign cure.

title: Sonnet CLIII
couplet: But at my mistress' eye Love's brand new-fired,/The boy for trial needs would touch my breast;

title: Sonnet CLIII
couplet: I, sick withal, the help of bath desired,/And thither hied, a sad distemper'd guest,

title: Sonnet CLIII
couplet: But found no cure: the bath for my help lies/  Where Cupid got new fire--my mistress' eyes.

title: Sonnet CLIV
couplet: The little Love-god lying once asleep/Laid by his side his heart-inflaming brand,

title: Sonnet CLIV
couplet: Whilst many nymphs that vow'd chaste life to keep/Came tripping by; but in her maiden hand

title: Sonnet CLIV
couplet: The fairest votary took up that fire/Which many legions of true hearts had warm'd;

title: Sonnet CLIV
couplet: And so the general of hot desire/Was sleeping by a virgin hand disarm'd.

title: Sonnet CLIV
couplet: This brand she quenched in a cool well by,/Which from Love's fire took heat perpetual,

title: Sonnet CLIV
couplet: Growing a bath and healthful remedy/For men diseased; but I, my mistress' thrall,

title: Sonnet CLIV
couplet: Came there for cure, and this by that I prove,/  Love's fire heats water, water cools not love.
